Summary 0:
Cross-border distribution of collective investment undertakings Cross-border distribution of collective investment undertakings SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1156 on facilitating cross-border distribution of collective investment undertakings WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to facilitate the cross-border distribution of alternative investment funds (AIFs)* and collective investment undertakings (UCITS)* in the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to all AIFs and UCITS, including European venture capital funds (EuVECA), European social entrepreneurship funds (EuSEF), European long-term investment funds (ELTIF) and European social entrepreneurship funds (EuSEF) as defined in Directive 2011/61/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council, as well as to collective investment undertakings for collective investment in transferable securities (UCITS) within the meaning of Directive 2009/65/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council. Regulation (EU) 2019/1156 applies to both companies, the regular business of which is the management of AIFs and UCITS, and to any UCITS which has not designated a UCITS management company. All marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be identifiable as such, and should describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or UCITS in an equally prominent manner. To safeguard investor protection and secure a level playing field between AIFs and UCITS, all information included in marketing communications addressed to investors should be presented in a manner that is fair, clear and not misleading. The marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be presented in a manner that is fair, clear and not misleading. To safeguard investor protection and secure a level playing field between AIFs and UCITS, all information included in marketing communications addressed to investors should be presented in a manner that is fair, clear and not misleading. The marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be identifiable as such, and should describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or UCITS in an equally prominent manner. The marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be presented in a manner that is fair, clear and not misleading. The marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be identifiable as such, and should describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or UCITS in an equally prominent manner. The marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be identifiable as such, and should describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or UCITS in an equally prominent manner. The marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be identifiable as such, and should describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or UCITS in an equally prominent manner. The marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be identifiable as such, and should describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or UCITS in an equally prominent manner. The marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be identifiable as such, and should describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or UCITS in an equally prominent manner. The marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be identifiable as such, and should describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or UCITS in an equally prominent manner. The marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be identifiable as such, and should describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or UCITS in an equally prominent manner. The marketing communications addressed to investors in AIFs and UCITS should be identifiable as such, and should describe the risks and rewards of purchasing units or shares of an AIF or UCITS in an equally prominent manner. Market surveillance and compliance of products Market surveillance and compliance of products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 on market surveillance and compliance of products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that products placed on the European Union (EU) market comply with EU harmonisation legislation. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to all products placed on the EU market, regardless of whether they are manufactured in the EU or not. It does not apply to products placed on the EU market via offline or online means and regardless of whether they are manufactured in the EU or not. Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 applies to all products placed on the EU market, regardless of whether they are manufactured in the EU or not. It does not apply to products placed on the EU market via offline or online means and regardless of whether they are manufactured in the EU or not. Licensing of copyright and related rights applicable to online transmissions of broadcasting organisations and retransmissions of television and radio programmes Licensing of copyright and related rights applicable to online transmissions of broadcasting organisations and retransmissions of television and radio programmes SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/789 — rules on the exercise of copyright and related rights applicable to certain online transmissions of broadcasting organisations and retransmissions of television and radio programmes WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It lays down rules on the exercise of copyright and related rights applicable to certain online transmissions of broadcasting organisations and retransmissions of television and radio programmes. It aims to facilitate the licensing of copyright and related rights in works and other protected subject matter contained in broadcasts of certain types of television and radio programmes, for the benefit of users across the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS Scope The directive applies to online transmissions of broadcasting organisations and retransmissions of television and radio programmes that originate in other EU countries. It does not apply to: cable, satellite, digital terrestrial, mobile or closed-circuit IP-based networks, as well as the open internet; transmissions of television and radio programmes that originate in other EU countries but are not broadcast in the EU; transmissions of television and radio programmes that originate in other EU countries but are not broadcast in the EU; transmissions of television and radio programmes that originate in other EU countries but are not broadcast in the EU; Summary 3:
Implementation and functioning of the.eu top-level domain name Implementation and functioning of the.eu top-level domain name SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/517 on the implementation and functioning of the.eu top-level domain name WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the.eu top-level domain (TLD), one of the largest country code top-level domains (ccTLDs) in the world. KEY POINTS The.eu TLD was established by Regulation (EC) No 733/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council and by Commission Regulation (EC) No 874/2004. The.eu TLD is used by the EU institutions, agencies and bodies, including for European projects and initiatives. It promotes the use of, and access to, internet networks in accordance with Articles 170 and 171 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) by providing registration complementary to existing ccTLDs and to the global registration of generic TLDs. It should enable undertakings, organisations and natural persons within the EU to register a domain name under the.eu TLD. It should provide a clearly identifiable link with the EU and the European market place. Regulation (EU) 2019/517 amends and repeals Regulation (EC) No 733/2002 and Commission Regulation (EC) No 874/2004. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 19 April 2019. BACKGROUND For more information, see:.eu top-level domain (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2019/517 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 19 March 2019 on the implementation and functioning of the.eu top-level domain name and amending and repealing Regulation (EC) No 733/2002 and Commission Regulation (EC) No 874/2004 (OJ L 91, 29.3.2019, pp. 25-28) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2019/517 have been incorporated into the original document. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Summary 4:
Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/1153 establishing the Connecting Europe Facility WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF), a European Union (EU) programme designed to accelerate investment in the field of trans-European networks and to leverage funding from both the public and the private sectors, while increasing legal certainty and respecting the principle of technological neutrality. KEY POINTS The CEF is a European Union (EU) programme designed to accelerate investment in the field of trans-European networks and to leverage funding from both the public and the private sectors, while increasing legal certainty and respecting the principle of technological neutrality. The CEF contributes to EU action against climate change and supports environmentally and socially sustainable projects, including, where appropriate, climate change mitigation and adaptation actions. The CEF is managed by the European Commission. The CEF is funded by the European Investment Bank (EIB), the European Investment Bank (EIB), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Investment Bank (EIB). The CEF is managed by the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF), a European Union (EU) programme designed to accelerate investment in the field of trans-European networks and to leverage funding from both the public and the private sectors, while increasing legal certainty and respecting the principle of technological neutrality. The CEF is a European Union (EU) programme designed to accelerate investment in the field of trans-European networks and to leverage funding from both the public and the private sectors, while increasing legal certainty and respecting the principle of technological neutrality. The CEF is managed by the European Commission. Ensuring the smooth functioning of the digital single market in an open and democratic society Ensuring the smooth functioning of the digital single market in an open and democratic society SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/784 — addressing the dissemination of terrorist content online WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure the smooth functioning of the digital single market in an open and democratic society by addressing the misuse of hosting services for terrorist purposes and contributing to public security across the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS The regulation applies to hosting service providers (i.e. companies that provide hosting services on the internet) and to video-sharing platforms (i.e. platforms that allow users to upload and share video content). It does not affect the fundamental rights of hosting service providers to receive and impart information and ideas in an open and democratic society, including the freedom to receive and impart information and ideas in an open and democratic society and the freedom and pluralism of the media. The regulation does not affect the application of Directive 2000/31/EC in relation to the misuse of hosting services for the purpose of carrying out illegal activities online, while taking into account the fundamental rights associated with their services online, including the freedom to receive and impart information and ideas in an open and democratic society and the freedom and pluralism of the media. The regulation does not affect the liability of hosting service providers for the misuse of their services by third parties for the purpose of carrying out illegal activities online, while taking into account the fundamental rights associated with their services online, including the freedom to receive and impart information and ideas in an open and democratic society and the freedom and pluralism of the media. The regulation does not affect the liability of hosting service providers for the misuse of their services by third parties for the purpose of carrying out illegal activities online, while taking into account the fundamental rights associated with their services online, including the freedom to receive and impart information and ideas in an open and democratic society and the freedom and pluralism of the media. Horizon Europe — the framework programme for research and innovation Horizon Europe — the framework programme for research and innovation SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/695 — the rules for participation and dissemination of Horizon Europe — the framework programme for research and innovation WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes Horizon Europe — the framework programme for research and innovation (R&I) for the period 2021-2027. It sets out the rules for participation and dissemination of the R&I programme. KEY POINTS The R&I programme supports the creation, better diffusion and transfer of high-quality and excellent knowledge and high-quality technologies in the EU, attract talent at all levels and contribute to full engagement of the EU's talent pool. It aims to strengthen the European research area (ERA) in which researchers, scientific knowledge and technology circulate freely and encourage it to become more competitive, including in its industry, while promoting all research and innovation (R&I) activities to deliver on the EU's strategic priorities and commitments, which ultimately aim to promote peace, the Union's values and the well-being of its peoples. The R&I programme supports the creation, better diffusion and transfer of high-quality and excellent knowledge and high-quality technologies in the EU, attract talent at all levels and contribute to full engagement of the EU's talent pool. It aims to strengthen the European research area (ERA) in which researchers, scientific knowledge and technology circulate freely and encourage it to become more competitive, including in its industry, while promoting all research and innovation (R&I) activities to deliver on the EU's strategic priorities and commitments, which ultimately aim to promote peace, the Union's values and the well-being of its peoples. EU Space Programme and the European Union Agency for the Space Programme EU Space Programme and the European Union Agency for the Space Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/696 establishing the Union Space Programme and the European Union Agency for the Space Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Union Space Programme (USP) and the European Union Agency for the Space Programme (ESAP). The USP is the EU’s main space policy initiative. The ESAP is the EU’s main space policy agency. It is responsible for developing and implementing the EU’s space policy. KEY POINTS The USP is the EU’s main space policy initiative. It is responsible for developing and implementing the EU’s space policy. The ESAP is the EU’s main space policy agency. It is responsible for developing and implementing the EU’s space policy. The ESAP is the EU’s main space policy agency. It is responsible for developing and implementing the EU’s space policy. The ESAP is the EU’s main space policy agency. It is responsible for developing and implementing the EU’s space policy. It is responsible for developing and implementing the EU’s space policy. It is responsible for developing and implementing the EU’s space policy. It is responsible for developing and implementing the EU’s space policy. It is responsible for developing and implementing the EU’s space policy. It is responsible for developing and implementing the EU’s space policy. Summary 8:
Financial envelope for the Digital Europe Programme Financial envelope for the Digital Europe Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/694 establishing the Digital Europe Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the financial envelope for the Digital Europe Programme (the ‘Programme’) for the period 2021-2027, which is to constitute the prime reference amount, within the meaning of point 18 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2020 between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management, as well as on new own resources, including a roadmap towards the introduction of new own resources, for the European Parliament and for the Council during the annual budgetary procedure. It repeals Decision (EU) 2015/2240 and replaces it with Regulation (EU) 2021/694. KEY POINTS The Digital Europe Programme is a multiannual financial framework (MFF) for the period 2021-2027, which is to align its duration with that of the multiannual financial framework laid down in Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2020/2093 (MFF 2021-2027). The MFF 2021-2027 has the power to carry out administrative checks and inspections, with a view to establishing the rules and objectives of the programme and ensuring that any third parties involved in the implementation of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity affecting the EU’s financial interests are eligible for funding. The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) has the power to carry out administrative checks and inspections, with a view to establishing the rules and objectives of the programme and ensuring that any third parties involved in the implementation of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity affecting the EU’s financial interests are eligible for funding. The European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPO) has the power to carry out administrative checks and inspections, with a view to establishing the rules and objectives of the programme and ensuring that any third parties involved in the implementation of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity affecting the EU’s financial interests are eligible for funding. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 11 May 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘Digital Europe’ on the European Commission’s website. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2021/694 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 29 April 2021 establishing the Digital Europe Programme and repealing Decision (EU) 2015/2240 (OJ L 166, 11.5.2021, pp. 1-8) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2021/694 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. RELATED DOCUMENTS Regulation (EU) 2020/2093 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 December 2020 laying down the financial framework for the period 2021-2027, which is to constitute the prime reference amount, within the meaning of point 18 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 16 December 2020 between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management, as well as on new own resources, including a roadmap towards the introduction of new own resources, for the European Parliament and for the Council during the annual budgetary procedure, for the European Parliament and for the Council during the annual budgetary procedure, and for the Council during the annual budgetary procedure. Control of the acquisition and possession of firearms Control of the acquisition and possession of firearms SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2021/555 on control of the acquisition and possession of weapons WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It sets out rules for the control of the acquisition and possession of firearms* in the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS The directive applies to all firearms and their essential components manufactured or imported into the EU. It does not apply to: hand-loading and reloading of ammunition from ammunition components for own use, or modifications of firearms or essential components owned by the person concerned, such as changes to the stock or sight, or maintenance to address wear and tear of essential components; modifications of firearms or essential components owned by the person concerned, such as changes to the stock or sight, or maintenance to address wear and tear of essential components; modifications of firearms or essential components owned by the person concerned, such as changes to the stock or sight, or maintenance to address wear and tear of essential components; Summary 11:
European Maritime Single Window European Maritime Single Window SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1239 establishing a European Maritime Single Window environment and repealing Directive 2010/65/EU WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules for the provision of the information that is required for port calls, in particular by ensuring that the same data sets can be reported to each maritime National Single Window in the same way. It also aims to facilitate the transmission of information between declarants, relevant authorities and the providers of port services in the port of call, and other EU countries. It repeals Directive 2010/65/EU. KEY POINTS EU countries must accept the reporting obligations of ships arriving in and departing from EU ports in electronic format and to ensure their transmission via a single window in order to facilitate and expedite maritime transport. The existing maritime National Single Window in each EU country should be maintained as the basis for a technologically neutral and interoperable European Maritime Single Window environment (‘EMSWe’). EMSWe is a comprehensive reporting entry point for maritime transport operators, performing the functionalities of data collection from the declarants and data distribution from the relevant authorities and providers of port services in the port of call. The EMSWe consists of a graphical user interface module and a graphical user interface for uploading data from the declarants, relevant authorities and the providers of port services in the port of call. EMSWe is managed by the European Commission and the European Maritime Safety Agency (EMSA). The EMSA is responsible for the development and operation of EMSWe at EU level. EMSWe is managed by the European Maritime Safety Agency (EMSA). EMSA is responsible for the development and operation of EMSWe at EU level. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 25 July 2019. BACKGROUND For more information, see: European Maritime Single Window (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2019/1239 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2019 establishing a European Maritime Single Window environment and repealing Directive 2010/65/EU (OJ L 198, 25.7.2019, pp. 64-89) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2019/1239 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. RELATED DOCUMENTS Directive 2010/65/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 June 2010 establishing a European Maritime Single Window environment and repealing Directive 2010/65/EU (OJ L 198, 25.7.2010, pp. 1-2) See consolidated version. European network of immigration liaison officers European network of immigration liaison officers SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1240 on the creation of a European network of immigration liaison officers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to strengthen EU policy in the field of migration by establishing a European network of immigration liaison officers. KEY POINTS The European network of immigration liaison officers (ENLOS) is composed of EU countries’ national authorities and the European Commission. The ENLOS are responsible for the management of immigration, including departures and returns, as well as the reintegration of migrants and applicants for international protection. The ENLOS are deployed by the national authorities of the EU countries and the Commission. The Commission is responsible for coordinating the deployment of the ENLOS. Summary 15:
Framework for interoperability between EU information systems in the field of borders and visas Framework for interoperability between EU information systems in the field of borders and visas SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/817 on establishing a framework for interoperability between EU information systems in the field of borders and visa WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a framework for interoperability between EU information systems in the field of borders and visas. It aims to improve the EU’s data management architecture for border management and security. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a high-level high-level expert group on information systems and interoperability. The group is composed of representatives from the European Commission, the European Parliament, the Council, the European Economic and Social Committee, the European Central Bank, the European Central Bank, the European Police College, the European Border and Coast Guard Association, the European Border and Coast Guard Association, the European Border and Coast Guard Association, the European Border and Coast Guard Association, the European Border and Coast Guard Association, the Schengen Information System, the European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS-TCN), the European Travel Information System (ETIS), the European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS-SIS) and the European Criminal Records Information System (ECRIS-TCN). The high-level expert group is responsible for the implementation of the interoperability framework. The Commission is responsible for the implementation of the interoperability framework. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 22 May 2019. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Interoperability of EU information systems (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2019/817 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2019 on establishing a framework for interoperability between EU information systems in the field of borders and visa and amending Regulations (EC) No 767/2008, (EU) 2016/399, (EU) 2017/2226, (EU) 2018/1240, (EU) 2018/1726 and (EU) 2018/1861 of the European Parliament and of the Council and Council Decisions 2004/512/EC and 2008/633/JHA (OJ L 135, 22.5.2019, pp. 27-28) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2019/817 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Promoting the use of energy from renewable sources Promoting the use of energy from renewable sources SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2018/2001 on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to promote the use of energy from renewable sources (i.e. wind, solar, hydro, geothermal, biomass, etc.) in the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS The directive requires EU countries to set a share of renewable energy in their national energy plans by 2030. The share of renewable energy in their national energy plans must be at least 32 % by 2030 and at least 40 % by 2050. The share of renewable energy in their national energy plans must be at least 32 % by 2030 and at least 40 % by 2050. The share of renewable energy in their national energy plans must be at least 32 % by 2030 and at least 40 % by 2050. Electronic Communications Code Electronic Communications Code SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2018/1972 establishing the European Electronic Communications Code WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to modernise the European Union’s (EU’s) regulatory framework for the provision of electronic communications networks and of electronic communications services. It is part of a ‘Regulatory Fitness’ (REFIT) exercise, the scope of which includes four Directives, namely 2002/19/EC, 2002/20/EC, 2002/21/EC and 2002/22/EC, and Regulation (EC) No 1211/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council. Directive (EU) 2018/1972 repeals Directives 2002/19/EC, 2002/20/EC, 2002/21/EC, 2002/22/EC and 2002/22/EC, as well as Regulation (EC) No 1211/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council. Monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles Monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/956 on the monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules on the monitoring and reporting of CO2 emissions from and fuel consumption of new heavy-duty vehicles. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to all new heavy-duty vehicles registered in the European Union (EU) between 1 January 2020 and 31 December 2024. It does not apply to new light-duty vehicles registered between 1 January 2020 and 31 December 2024. It does not apply to new medium-duty vehicles registered between 1 January 2020 and 31 December 2024. The regulation applies to all new heavy-duty vehicles registered in the EU between 1 January 2020 and 31 December 2024. Measures to safeguard the security of gas supply Measures to safeguard the security of gas supply SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/1938 — measures to safeguard the security of gas supply WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that all the necessary measures are taken to safeguard an uninterrupted supply of gas throughout the EU, in particular to protected customers in the event of difficult climatic conditions or disruptions of the gas supply. It repeals Regulation (EU) No 994/2010. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out a number of measures to safeguard the security of gas supply in the EU, in particular to protect protected customers in the event of a disruption of the gas supply. These measures include: establishing national emergency plans to deal with disruptions of the gas supply in the event of severe climatic conditions or disruptions of the gas supply in the event of a Protection of personal data Protection of personal data SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/679 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to protect the rights of natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data and the free movement of such data within the European Union (EU). It repeals Directive 95/46/EC (General Data Protection Regulation). KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data and to the free movement of such data within the EU. It does not apply to natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data outside the EU. Scope The regulation applies to natural persons with regard to the processing of their personal data and to the free movement of such data within the EU. Harmonised indices of consumer prices and the house price index Harmonised indices of consumer prices and the house price index SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/792 on harmonised indices of consumer prices and the house price index WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to establish a common framework for the development, production and dissemination of harmonised indices of consumer prices and of the house price index (HPI) at EU and national level. KEY POINTS The harmonised index of consumer prices (HICP) is designed to measure inflation in a harmonised manner across EU countries. The Commission and the European Central Bank use the HICP in their assessment of price stability in the EU under Article 140 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). Protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries Protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/1036 on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Union WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It codifies Regulation (EC) No 1225/2009 on protection against dumped imports from non-EU countries. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to imports of certain products from non-EU countries which are dumped into the EU market at below-market-value prices. It does not apply to imports of certain products from non-EU countries which are dumped into the EU market at above-market-value prices. It does not apply to imports of certain products from non-EU countries which are dumped into the EU market at below-market-value prices. The regulation sets out detailed rules on the calculation of dumping and on the procedure for initiating and pursuing an investigation. It does not apply to imports of certain products from non-EU countries which are dumped into the EU market at below-market-value prices. It does not apply to imports of certain products from non-EU countries which are dumped into the EU market at above-market-value prices. Recovery and resilience Facility (RRF) Recovery and resilience Facility (RRF) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/241 establishing the Recovery and Resilience Facility WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) to help European Union (EU) countries recover from the effects of the 2008 financial crisis. KEY POINTS The RRF is designed to help European Union (EU) countries recover from the effects of the 2008 financial crisis and to strengthen their economic, social and territorial cohesion. It is funded by the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD). The RRF is designed to help EU countries recover from the effects of the 2008 financial crisis and to strengthen their economic, social and territorial cohesion. Rights and obligations for rail passengers Rights and obligations for rail passengers SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/782 on rail passengers’ rights and obligations WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rights and obligations of rail passengers in the European Union (EU). It recasts Regulation (EC) No 1371/2007 on rail passengers’ rights and obligations. KEY POINTS Regulation (EU) 2021/782 applies to all rail passenger services throughout the EU. It does not apply to: urban, suburban or regional rail passenger services; historic or touristic rail passenger services. It does not apply to: long-distance rail passenger services operated outside the EU; regional rail passenger services operated in regions where a significant part of the rail system is operated outside the EU. Summary 29:
Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/947 establishing the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument – Global Europe WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Neighbourhood, Development and International Cooperation Instrument (NDICI) for the period 2021-2027. It aims to uphold and promote the European Union’s (EU’s) values, principles and fundamental interests worldwide in order to pursue the objectives and principles of the EU’s external action, as laid down in Articles 8 and 21 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU). KEY POINTS The NDICI is a programme for the purpose of the multiannual financial framework (MFF). It contributes to the objectives and principles of the EU’s external action, as laid down in Articles 8 and 21 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU), as well as to work for a high degree of cooperation in all fields of international relations. The NDICI is a programme for the purpose of the multiannual financial framework (MFF). It contributes to the objectives and principles of the EU’s external action, as laid down in Articles 8 and 21 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU), as well as to work for a high degree of cooperation in all fields of international relations. The NDICI is a programme for the purpose of the multiannual financial framework (MFF). It aims to uphold and promote the European Union’s values, principles and fundamental interests worldwide in order to pursue the objectives and principles of the EU’s external action, as laid down in Articles 8 and 21 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU). The NDICI is a programme for the purpose of the multiannual financial framework (MFF). It contributes to the objectives and principles of the EU’s external action, as laid down in Articles 8 and 21 of the Treaty on European Union (TEU), as well as to work for a high degree of cooperation in all fields of international relations. Protection of persons who report breaches of EU law Protection of persons who report breaches of EU law SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/1937 on the protection of persons who report breaches of EU law WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to ensure that persons who report breaches of EU law are protected against any form of retaliation. KEY POINTS The directive applies to persons who work for a public or private organisation or are in contact with such an organisation in the context of their work-related activities. It does not apply to persons who work for a private organisation or are in contact with such an organisation in the context of their work-related activities. It does not apply to persons who work for a public or private organisation or are in contact with such an organisation in the context of their work-related activities. European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the EU European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the EU SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1896 on the European Border and Coast Guard and repealing Regulations (EU) No 1052/2013 and (EU) 2016/1624 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the European Union (Frontex). KEY POINTS The European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the European Union (Frontex) is responsible for: establishing a technical and operational strategy as part of the implementation of the multiannual strategic policy cycle for European integrated border management; to carry out risk analysis and vulnerability assessments; to oversee the effective functioning of border control at the external borders; to provide technical and operational assistance in the form of joint operations and rapid border interventions, risk analysis, information exchange, relations with third countries and the return of returnees. Cybersecurity certification for information and communications technology Cybersecurity certification for information and communications technology SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/881 on ENISA (the European Union Agency for Cybersecurity) and on information and communications technology cybersecurity certification and repealing Regulation (EU) No 526/2013 (Cybersecurity Act) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up the European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA) to provide cybersecurity certification for information and communications technology (ICT) products, services and devices. It repeals Regulation (EU) No 526/2013 (Cybersecurity Act). KEY POINTS The regulation sets up ENISA to provide cybersecurity certification for information and communications technology (ICT) products, services and devices used by citizens, organisations and businesses across the European Union (EU). It aims to improve cybersecurity in the EU so that network and information systems, communications networks, digital products, services and devices used by citizens, organisations and businesses, as defined in Commission Recommendation 2003/361/EC, are better protected from cyber threats. ENISA is responsible for issuing cybersecurity certification for ICT products, services and devices. The certification is based on a set of cybersecurity requirements, which are set out in Annex I to the regulation. The certification is issued by ENISA and is valid for a period of 5 years after the end of the certification period. The certification is valid for a period of 5 years after the end of the certification period. Harmonisation of gross national income at market prices Harmonisation of gross national income at market prices SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/516 on the harmonisation of gross national income at market prices WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that gross national income (GNI) at market prices* is comparable across EU countries and that there is compliance with the relevant definitions and accounting rules of the European System of Accounts (ESA 2010). It repeals Directive 89/130/EEC, Euratom and Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1287/2003 (GNI Regulation). KEY POINTS GNI is the basis for calculating the largest share of own resources in the general budget of the European Union (EU). It is also an important analytical tool for the coordination of national economic policies and for various EU policies, as well as for research activities. It is essential that the sources and methods used to compile GNI data are reliable. It is essential that sound techniques are applied to robust, suitable and up-to-date GNI data as much as possible. This means that sound techniques should be applied to robust, suitable and up-to-date GNI data as much as possible. It is essential that the sources and methods used to compile GNI data are reliable. EU type-approval legislation with regard to the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU EU type-approval legislation with regard to the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/26 — complementing EU type-approval legislation with regard to the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that EU type-approval legislation with regard to the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU will continue to apply to and in the United Kingdom during the transition period in accordance with the withdrawal agreement between the EU and the United Kingdom. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to all new vehicles, components and separate technical units that are to be placed on the EU market after the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU. It does not apply to vehicles, components and separate technical units already approved by the United Kingdom type-approval authority. Manufacturers wishing to place vehicles, components and separate technical units on the EU market after the withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU must first obtain a type-approval from the United Kingdom type-approval authority. European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/794 on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) and replaces and repeals Council Decisions 2009/371/JHA, 2009/934/JHA, 2009/935/JHA, 2009/936/JHA and 2009/968/JHA. KEY POINTS Europol is the European Union’s (EU’s) law enforcement agency responsible for preventing and combating serious crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more EU countries. It is funded by the EU’s general budget. Europol’s main objectives are to: support and strengthen action by competent authorities of the EU countries and their mutual cooperation in preventing and combating organised crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more EU countries; facilitate and facilitate a common approach in relation to acts of serious crime which are committed or perpetrate in relation to the interests of the EU; provide strategic and operational support to the Member States in laying down strategic and operational priorities in preventing and combating serious crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more EU countries; provide strategic and operational support to the Member States in laying down strategic and operational priorities in preventing and combating serious crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more EU countries; provide strategic and operational support to the Member States in laying down strategic and operational priorities in preventing and combating serious crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more EU countries; provide strategic and operational support to the Member States in laying down strategic and operational priorities in preventing and combating serious crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more EU countries; provide strategic and operational support to the Member States in laying down strategic and operational priorities in preventing and combating serious crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more EU countries; provide strategic and operational support to the Member States in laying down strategic and operational priorities in preventing and combating serious crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more EU countries; provide strategic and operational support to the Member States in laying down strategic and operational priorities in preventing and combating serious crime, terrorism and other forms of serious crime affecting two or more EU countries; EU instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency (SURE) following the COVID-19 outbreak EU instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency (SURE) following the COVID-19 outbreak SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2020/672 on the establishment of a European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency (SURE) following the COVID-19 outbreak WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency (SURE) following the COVID-19 outbreak. KEY POINTS The COVID-19 outbreak has had a massive and disruptive impact on the economic systems of the EU countries, caused societal disruptions and increased public expenditure in a growing number of EU countries. It is beyond the control of the EU countries and which has immobilised a substantial part of their labour force, has led to a sudden and severe increase in public expenditure by the EU countries on short-time work schemes for employees and similar measures, in particular for the self-employed, as well as expenditure on some health-related measures, in particular in the workplace. Recovery and resolution of central counterparties (CCPs) Recovery and resolution of central counterparties (CCPs) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/23 on a framework for the recovery and resolution of central counterparties WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that central counterparties (CCPs) in the European Union (EU) are able to continue to function in the event of financial distress or at the point of failure of a financial institution. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a framework for the recovery and resolution of central counterparties (CCPs) in the event of financial distress or at the point of failure of a financial institution. It aims to promote sustainable and smart mobility in the European Union (EU) through a European Year of Rail (2021). It is part of the European Green Deal. KEY POINTS The European Year of Rail aims to promote sustainable and smart mobility in the European Union (EU) through a European Year of Rail (2021). It is part of the European Green Deal. The European Green Deal is a new growth strategy that aims to transform the EU into a fair and prosperous society, with a modern, resource-efficient and competitive economy where there are no net emissions of greenhouse gases in 2050 and where economic growth is decoupled from resource use. To achieve climate neutrality by 2050, a 90 % reduction in transport emissions is needed by 2050. To achieve that, the rail sector must play an essential role in both the supply of essential goods and the provision of cross-border freight services. European Security and Defence College (ESDC) European Security and Defence College (ESDC) SUMMARY OF: Decision (CFSP) 2020/1515 establishing a European Security and Defence College WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It establishes the European Security and Defence College (ESDC) to provide training and education in the field of the EU’s Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) in the wider context of the Common Foreign and Security Initiative (CFSP) at European level in order to develop and promote a common understanding of CFSP and CSDP among civilian and military personnel and to identify and disseminate best practices in relation to various CFSP and CSDP, issues through its training and education activities. KEY POINTS The ESDC provides training and education in the field of the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) in the wider context of the Common Foreign and Security Initiative (CFSP) at European level in order to develop and promote a common understanding of CFSP and CSDP among civilian and military personnel and to identify and disseminate best practices in relation to various CFSP and CSDP, issues through its training and education activities. The main tasks of the ESDC are to provide training and education in the field of CSDP in the wider context of the CFSP at European level in order to develop and promote a common understanding of CFSP and CSDP among civilian and military personnel and to identify and disseminate best practices in relation to various CFSP and CSDP, issues through its training and education activities. Minimum requirements for water reuse Minimum requirements for water reuse SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2020/741 on minimum requirements for water reuse WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down minimum requirements for water reuse* in the European Union (EU). It aims to encourage the reuse of treated waste water (TWW) in order to reduce water scarcity and improve the water quality of the EU’s water resources. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the minimum requirements for the reuse of TWW in the EU. It does not apply to surface water bodies or groundwater bodies. It does not apply to groundwater bodies. The Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund The Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/1147 — establishing the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF), a European Union (EU) instrument designed to support EU countries’ efforts to manage migration. KEY POINTS The AMIF is funded by the EU’s external borders fund, the European Migration and Integration Fund (EMIF), which is managed by the European Commission. The AMIF’s main objective is to support EU countries’ efforts to manage migration and to prevent and adequately handle situations of pressure in solidarity, and to replace irregular and unsafe arrivals with legal and safe pathways. The AMIF is funded by the EU’s external borders fund, the European Migration and Integration Fund (EMIF), which is managed by the European Commission. The AMIF’s main objective is to support EU countries’ efforts to manage migration and to prevent and adequately handle situations of pressure in solidarity, and to replace irregular and unsafe arrivals with legal and safe pathways. It is funded by the EU’s external borders fund, the European Migration and Integration Fund (EMIF), which is managed by the European Commission. The AMIF’s main objective is to support EU countries’ efforts to manage migration and to prevent and adequately handle situations of pressure in solidarity, and to replace irregular and unsafe arrivals with legal and safe pathways. It is funded by the EU’s external borders fund, the European Migration and Integration Fund (EMIF), which is managed by the European Commission. The EU’s external borders fund, the European Migration and Integration Fund (EMIF), which is managed by the European Commission. The AMIF’s main objective is to support EU countries’ efforts to manage migration and to prevent and adequately handle situations of pressure in solidarity, and to replace irregular and unsafe arrivals with legal and safe pathways. It is funded by the EU’s external borders fund, the European Migration and Integration Fund (EMIF), which is managed by the European Commission. The EU’s external borders fund, the European Migration and Integration Fund (EMIF), which is managed by the European Commission. The AMIF’s main objective is to support EU countries’ efforts to manage migration and to prevent and adequately handle situations of pressure in solidarity, and to replace irregular and unsafe arrivals with legal and safe pathways. It is funded by the EU’s external borders fund, the European Migration and Integration Fund (EMIF), which is managed by the European Commission. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 15 July 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2021/1147 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 7 July 2021 establishing the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (OJ L 251, 15.7.2021, pp. 1-8) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2021/1147 have been incorporated in the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Summary 43:
Work-life balance for parents and carers Work-life balance for parents and carers SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/1158 on work-life balance for parents and carers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to promote a work-life balance for parents and carers in the European Union (EU). It repeals Directive 2010/18/EU. KEY POINTS Scope The directive applies to parents and carers of children under the age of 18. It does not apply to parents and carers of children under the age of 18. It does not apply to parents and carers of children under the age of 18. Parental leave The directive requires EU countries to ensure that parents and carers of children under the age of 18 receive at least 12 weeks of paid parental leave. It does not apply to parents and carers of children under the age of 18. It does not apply to parents and carers of children under the age of 18. Regulation (EU) 2015/751 on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions Regulation (EU) 2015/751 on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2015/751 on interchange fees for card-based payment transactions WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the functioning of the European Union’s (EU’s) internal market for payments by establishing uniform rules on interchange fees* for card-based payment transactions. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to all card-based payment transactions in the EU, irrespective of whether they are carried out in cash or electronic form. It does not apply to credit transfers or direct debits. It does not apply to cross-border payments. European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust) European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/1727 on the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust), and replacing and repealing Council Decision 2002/187/JHA WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust) to support and strengthen coordination and cooperation between national investigating and prosecuting authorities in relation to serious crime affecting two or more EU countries or requiring prosecution on common bases, on the basis of operations conducted and information supplied by the Member States’ authorities and by the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). KEY POINTS Eurojust’s mission is to support and strengthen coordination and cooperation between national investigating and prosecuting authorities in relation to serious crime affecting two or more EU countries or requiring prosecution on common bases, on the basis of operations conducted and information supplied by the Member States’ authorities and by the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol). Eurojust’s legal framework has been amended by Council Decisions 2003/659/JHA and 2009/426/JHA. It also requires determining arrangements for involving the European Parliament and national parliaments in the evaluation of Eurojust’s activities. Eurojust’s legal framework has been amended by Council Decisions 2003/659/JHA and 2009/426/JHA. It also requires determining arrangements for involving the European Parliament and national parliaments in the evaluation of Eurojust’s activities. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 21 November 2018. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Eurojust on the European Commission’s website. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2018/1727 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 November 2018 on the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust), and replacing and repealing Council Decision 2002/187/JHA (OJ L 295, 21.11.2018, pp. 138-151) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2018/1727 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. RELATED DOCUMENTS Council Decision 2003/659/JHA of 20 December 2003 on the European Union Agency for Criminal Justice Cooperation (Eurojust) (OJ L 294, 20.12.2013, pp. 1-2) See consolidated version. Council Decision 2009/426/JHA of 20 December 2009 on the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (Europol) (OJ L 294, 20.12.2013, pp. 1-2) See consolidated version. Combating money laundering by means of criminal law Combating money laundering by means of criminal law SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2018/1673 — combating money laundering by means of criminal law WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to combat money laundering by means of criminal law. KEY POINTS Money laundering is a criminal offence that involves the transfer of funds from one person to another in order to finance criminal activities, such as drug trafficking, terrorism or the financing of organised crime. Predicate offences for money laundering are those that involve the transfer of funds from one person to another in order to finance criminal activities, such as drug trafficking, terrorism or the financing of organised crime. Summary 52:
Multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean Multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/1627 on a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean. It repeals Regulation (EC) No 302/2009. KEY POINTS The recovery plan is based on the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) Recommendation 06-05 establishing a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean ending in 2022. The recovery plan takes into account the specificities of the different types of gear and fishing techniques. The EU and EU countries must endeavour to promote fishing activities and the use of fishing gear and techniques which are selective and have a reduced environmental impact, including gear and techniques used in traditional and artisanal fisheries, thereby contributing to a fair standard of living for local economies. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 14 September 2016. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Bluefin tuna (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2016/1627 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 September 2016 on a multiannual recovery plan for bluefin tuna in the eastern Atlantic and the Mediterranean, and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 302/2009 (OJ L 252, 16.9.2016, pp. 1-8) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2016/1627 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Cableway installations — essential requirements Cableway installations — essential requirements SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/424 on cableway installations WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down essential requirements for cableway installations*. It repeals Directive 2000/9/EC on cableway installations. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to cableway installations that are designed, constructed and operated with a view to transporting persons. It does not apply to cableway installations that are used in urban transport facilities or in high-altitude tourist facilities. Accessibility requirements for products and services Accessibility requirements for products and services SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2019/882 on the accessibility requirements for products and services WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to increase the availability of accessible products and services in the EU by approximating laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States as regards accessibility requirements for certain products and services by, in particular, eliminating and preventing barriers to the free movement of certain accessible products and services arising from divergent accessibility requirements in the Member States. It also aims to improve the accessibility of relevant information. KEY POINTS Scope The directive applies to: products and services that are intended to be used by persons with disabilities; products and services that are intended to be used by persons who have any physical, mental, intellectual or sensory impairments, age related impairments, or other human body performance related causes, permanent or temporary. Scope The directive applies to: products and services intended to be used by persons with disabilities; products and services intended to be used by persons who have any physical, mental, intellectual or sensory impairments, age related impairments, or other human body performance related causes, permanent or temporary. EU supply chain due diligence obligations for tin, tantalum and tungsten, their ores, and gold originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas EU supply chain due diligence obligations for tin, tantalum and tungsten, their ores, and gold originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/821 — supply chain due diligence obligations for EU importers of tin, tantalum and tungsten, their ores, and gold originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down supply chain due diligence (SDR) obligations for EU importers of tin, tantalum and tungsten, their ores, and gold originating from conflict-affected and high-risk areas. It aims to prevent the financing of armed groups and security forces in resource-rich areas. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to all EU importers of tin, tantalum and tungsten, their ores, and gold originating from conflict-affected or high-risk areas. It does not apply to: imports of gold originating from conflict-affected or high-risk areas; imports of gold originating from conflict-affected or high-risk areas; imports of gold originating from conflict-affected or high-risk areas; EU customs code EU customs code SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 — recasting the EU customs code WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It recasts Regulation (EC) No 450/2008 on the EU customs code (modernised customs code). It aims to ensure uniform conditions for the implementation of the EU customs code. KEY POINTS Regulation (EU) No 952/2013 lays down the format and code of the common data requirements for the purpose of the exchange of information between the customs authorities and between economic operators and customs authorities and the storage of such information and the procedural rules on the exchange and storage of information which can be made by means other than electronic data-processing techniques. It allows one or several Member States to use means for the exchange and storage of information other than electronic data-processing techniques; to adopt decisions allowing one or several Member States to use means for the exchange and storage of information other than electronic data-processing techniques; to specify the technical arrangements for developing and maintaining the customs authority which is responsible for the registration of economic operators and of other persons; to specify the customs authority which is responsible for developing and maintaining the customs authority which is responsible for the management of specific goods; to specify the procedural rules regarding the application of customs controls and formalities; to lay down the criteria for determining the status of a comprehensive risk information and analysis; to specify the criteria for the granting of a guarantee or a guarantee on the granting of customs controls and formalities; to specify the procedural rules regarding the granting of a temporary derogation on the application of customs controls; to specify the procedural rules relating to the granting of preferential measures on specific goods; to specify the procedural rules relating to the granting of preferential measures on the taking and the verification of the proof of origin of goods; to specify the procedural rules on the verification of the proof of the origin of goods; to specify the procedural rules relating to the granting of preferential measures on the taking and the verification of the proof of the origin of goods; to specify the procedural rules relating to the granting of preferential measures on the taking and the verification of the proof of the origin of goods; Customs enforcement of intellectual property rights Customs enforcement of intellectual property rights SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 608/2013 concerning customs enforcement of intellectual property rights and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1383/2003 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to strengthen the enforcement of intellectual property rights by customs authorities in the European Union (EU). It repeals Council Regulation (EC) No 1383/2003 concerning customs action against goods suspected of infringing certain intellectual property rights and the measures to be taken against goods found to have infringed such rights. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to goods which, in accordance with EU customs legislation, are liable to customs supervision or customs control, and to carry out adequate controls on such goods with a view to preventing operations in breach of intellectual property rights laws. Customs authorities are competent to enforce intellectual property rights with regard to goods, which, in accordance with EU customs legislation, are liable to customs supervision or customs control, and to carry out adequate controls on such goods with a view to preventing operations in breach of intellectual property rights laws. Where the goods are suspended or detained by customs authorities at the border, only one legal proceeding is required, whereas several separate proceedings should be required for the same level of enforcement for goods found on the market, which have been disaggregated and delivered to retailers. Customs programme for cooperation in the field of customs Customs programme for cooperation in the field of customs SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/444 establishing the Customs programme for cooperation in the field of customs WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Customs programme for cooperation in the field of customs and repeals Regulation (EU) No 1294/2013. It aims to facilitate and enhance customs cooperation between European Union (EU) countries and the European Commission. KEY POINTS The programme is designed to support the effective collection of customs duties and the fight against fraud and illegal cross-border flows of goods. It also aims to protect the EU’s financial interests by supporting the effective collection of customs duties and the fight against fraud and illegal cross-border flows of goods. European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/1057 establishing the European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) and repealing Regulation (EU) No 1296/2013 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Social Fund Plus (ESF+), the successor to the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF). It aims to contribute to the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights (the ‘Pillar’) by supporting investments in people and systems in the policy areas of employment, education and social inclusion, thereby supporting economic, territorial and social cohesion in accordance with Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). It repeals Regulation (EU) No 1296/2013. KEY POINTS The European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) is the successor to the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF). It aims to contribute to the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights (the ‘Pillar’) by supporting investments in people and systems in the policy areas of employment, education and social inclusion, thereby supporting economic, territorial and social cohesion in accordance with Article 174 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The European Pillar of Social Rights (the ‘Pillar’) was jointly proclaimed by the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission as a response to social challenges in Europe. The 20 key principles of the Pillar are structured in three categories: equal opportunities and access to the labour market; fair working conditions; and social protection and inclusion. The European Pillar of Social Rights (the ‘Pillar’) was jointly proclaimed by the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission as a response to social challenges in Europe. European Solidarity Corps Programme European Solidarity Corps Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/888 establishing the European Solidarity Corps Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Solidarity Corps (ESC) programme, which aims to mobilise young people from across the European Union (EU) to take part in humanitarian aid projects in developing countries. KEY POINTS The ESC is open to EU citizens between the ages of 18 and 30 who are interested in volunteering in humanitarian aid projects in developing countries. Transparency register for interest representatives Transparency register for interest representatives SUMMARY OF: INTERINSTITUTIONAL AGREEMENT between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on a mandatory transparency register WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE AGREEMENT AND OF THE DECISION? The agreement establishes a joint framework for cooperation between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on a mandatory transparency register for interest representatives*. The decision adopts the agreement on behalf of the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS The agreement establishes a joint framework for cooperation between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on a mandatory transparency register for interest representatives*. The agreement applies to associations, bodies, offices and agencies that apply for membership of an association or network of public authorities at EU level. It does not apply to associations, bodies, offices and agencies that apply for membership of an association or network of public authorities at national or subnational level. Summary 64:
Interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management, as well as on new own resources Interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management, as well as on new own resources SUMMARY OF: Interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management, as well as on new own resources Interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management, as well as on new own resources WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE AGREEMENT AND OF THE AGREEMENT? The agreement aims to improve the functioning of the annual budgetary procedure and cooperation between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on budgetary matters as well as to ensure sound financial management. It also aims to introduce a roadmap towards the introduction, over the period of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2021-2027, of new own resources that are sufficient to cover the repayment of the European Union Recovery Instrument established under Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2020/2093. KEY POINTS The agreement covers all expenditure. It does not alter the respective budgetary and legislative powers of the institutions as laid down in the Treaties, in Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2020/2093, in Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 of the European Parliament and of the Council, and in Council Decision (EU, Euratom) 2020/2053 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The agreement does not alter the respective budgetary and legislative powers of the institutions as laid down in the Treaties, in Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2020/2093, in Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 of the European Parliament and of the Council, and in Council Decision (EU, Euratom) 2020/2053 of the European Parliament and of the Council, and is without prejudice to the powers of national parliaments in respect of own resources. The agreement contains four parts: Part I contains provisions related to the multiannual financial framework (MFF); Part II contains provisions related to the thematic and non-thematic special instruments; Part III contains provisions related to the sound financial management of the EU budget; Part IV contains provisions related to the implementation of the financial regulation; Part V contains provisions related to the implementation of the financial regulation. FROM WHEN DOES THE INTERINSTITUTIONAL AGREEMENT APPLY? It entered into force on 16 December 2020. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Budgetary discipline (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENTS Interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on budgetary discipline, on cooperation in budgetary matters and on sound financial management, as well as on new own resources (OJ L 433, 22.12.2020, pp. 28-35) Council Decision (EU, Euratom) 2020/2053 of 16 December 2020 on the introduction, over the period of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2021-2027, of new own resources that are sufficient to cover the repayment of the European Union Recovery Instrument established under Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2020/2093 (OJ L 434, 22.12.2020, pp. 1-2) RELATED DOCUMENTS Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 2 December 2013 on the financial regulation (the "Financial Regulation"), in Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2020/2093, in Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 of the European Parliament and of the Council, and in Council Decision (EU, Euratom) 2020/2053 (OJ L 434, 22.12.2013, pp. 1-2) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU, Euratom) 2018/1046 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Summary 65:
European Union recovery instrument to support the recovery in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis European Union recovery instrument to support the recovery in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2020/2094 establishing a European Union recovery instrument to support the recovery in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes a European Union (EU) recovery instrument to support the recovery in the aftermath of the COVID-19 crisis. KEY POINTS The COVID-19 crisis was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization on 11 March 2020. In order to contain the spread of COVID-19, EU countries have adopted a set of unprecedented measures. The unprecedented measures taken in response to the exceptional situation caused by COVID-19, which is beyond the control of Member States, have caused significant disturbances to economic activity which are reflected in a steep decline in gross domestic product and a significant impact on employment, social conditions, poverty and inequalities. Effective enforcement of budgetary surveillance in the euro area Effective enforcement of budgetary surveillance in the euro area SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1173/2011 on the effective enforcement of budgetary surveillance in the euro area WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules and procedures for the effective enforcement of budgetary surveillance* in the euro area. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the rules and procedures for the effective enforcement of budgetary surveillance in the euro area. It applies to all EU countries that use the euro. It does not apply to non-euro area countries such as Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland. The European Commission, the European Central Bank (ECB) and the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) monitor the implementation of the euro area’s Stability and Growth Pact (SGP) and the euro area’s economic governance framework. It aims to ensure that the European Union (EU) is in possession of sufficient reliable, detailed and comparable data on the population and housing, in order to enable the European Commission (Eurostat) to fulfil the tasks assigned to it, in particular by Articles 2 and 3 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
