Rules of procedure of the European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) Rules of procedure of the European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS) SUMMARY OF: Decision of the European Data Protection Supervisor of 15 May 2020 adopting the rules of procedure of the European Data Protection Supervisor WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It sets out the strategic priorities of the European Data Protection Supervisor (EDPS). KEY POINTS The EDPS is responsible for ensuring that EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies respect the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data. The EDPS acts in accordance with the provisions of Regulation (EU) 2018/1725 on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data by EU institutions, bodies, offices and agencies and repealing Regulation (EC) No 45/2001 and Decision No 1247/2002/EC. The EDPS is assisted by a secretariat and lays down a number of provisions concerning staff and budgetary matters. The EDPS may act as an expert in the field of data protection, including internal governance and good administrative behaviour. The EDPS may act as an expert in the field of data protection, including internal communication and good administrative behaviour. The EDPS may engage openly and transparently with the media and stakeholders, as well as with any other public authority established by Article 53 of the GDPR. The EDPS may adopt strategic priorities and an annual report in accordance with Article 53 of the GDPR. The EDPS may engage openly and transparently with the media and stakeholders, as well as with any other public authority established by Article 53 of the GDPR. It sets out the system of own resources of the European Union (EU) for the period 2021-2027. It repeals Decision 2014/335/EU, Euratom. KEY POINTS The system of own resources of the EU is designed to ensure adequate resources for the orderly development of the policies of the EU, subject to the need for strict budgetary discipline. European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/1173 on establishing the European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking and repealing Regulation (EU) 2018/1488 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking and repeals Regulation (EU) 2018/1488 on the European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking. KEY POINTS The European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking is a joint undertaking between the European Commission, the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom) and the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom). The European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking supports the implementation of projects of common interest which aim at the acquisition, deployment and operation of a world-class supercomputing, quantum and data infrastructure, at federation and interconnection, and at widening the use of supercomputing services and the development of key skills. The European High Performance Computing Joint Undertaking supports the implementation of projects of common interest which aim at the development and construction of new infrastructures and services, or at the upgrading of existing infrastructures and services, in the transport, telecommunications and energy sectors. Framework for achieving climate neutrality Framework for achieving climate neutrality SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/1119 establishing the framework for achieving climate neutrality and amending Regulations (EC) No 401/2009 and (EU) 2018/1999 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the framework for achieving climate neutrality and amending Regulations (EC) No 401/2009 and (EU) 2018/1999 (the ‘European Climate Law’). KEY POINTS The European Union (EU) is committed to stepping up efforts to tackle climate change and to delivering on the implementation of the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (the ‘Paris Agreement’), guided by its principles and on the basis of the best available scientific knowledge, in the context of the long-term temperature goal of the Paris Agreement. To achieve climate neutrality, the EU aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40 % by 2030 compared to 1990 levels. To achieve climate neutrality, the EU aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 40 % by 2030 compared to 1990 levels. Creative Europe Programme Creative Europe Programme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/818 establishing the Creative Europe Programme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Creative Europe Programme (CEAP) for the period 2021 to 2027. It aims to promote, protect and enhance Europe’s rich cultural and linguistic diversity. KEY POINTS The CEAP is a European Union (EU) programme for the period 2021 to 2027. It aims to promote, protect and enhance Europe’s rich cultural and linguistic diversity. It is based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and the respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to a minority. It also contributes to the creation, innovation and sustainable growth in the cultural and creative sectors, and to the construction of a single market for cultural and creative products. The CEAP is funded by the European Investment Bank (EIB), the European Commission, the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF). The CEAP is open to all EU countries and the European Economic Area (EEA) countries (Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Switzerland, Turkey, Croatia, Greece, Romania, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czechia, Hungary, Poland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Finland, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovenia, Serbia, Slovakia and Ukraine). The CEAP is open to all EU countries and the EEA countries and the European Investment Bank (EIB), the European Commission, the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF). FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 28 May 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Creative Europe Programme (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2021/818 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2021 establishing the Creative Europe Programme (2021 to 2027) and repealing Regulation (EU) No 1295/2013 (OJ L 189, 28.5.2021, pp. 34-37) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2021/818 have been incorporated into the original document. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. RELATED DOCUMENTS Communication from the Commission to the European Parliament, the Council, the European Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions and the Committee of the Regions of 22 May 2018 entitled ‘A New European Agenda for Culture’. This communication sets out objectives for social cohesion and societal well-being by fostering the power of culture and cultural diversity. It aims to harness the power of culture and cultural diversity by fostering the cross-border production, dissemination and consumption of cultural and creative content, in line with the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights and the Unesco 2005 Convention on the Protection and Promotion of Cultural Expressions (OJ L 183, 29.5.2018, pp. 1-23). Strategic Innovation Agenda of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) Strategic Innovation Agenda of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) SUMMARY OF: Decision (EU) 2021/820 on the Strategic Innovation Agenda of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) 2021-2027 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It sets out the strategic innovation agenda (SIA) of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) for the period 2021-2027. KEY POINTS The SIA sets out the priority fields and the strategy for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) for the seven-year period concerned in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2021/695 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The SIA should establish the EIT’s key actions and should include an assessment of the EIT’s expected social, economic and environmental impact, its outreach activities and its capacity to generate best innovation added-value. The SIA should also take into account the results of the continuous monitoring and periodic independent evaluation of the EIT. The EIT should also take into account the strategic planning of Horizon Europe – the Framework Programme for Research and Innovation (Horizon Europe), established by Regulation (EU) 2021/695, establish and appropriate foster synergies and complementarities between EIT activities and other relevant Union, national and regional initiatives, instruments and programmes, and ensure consistency with Union priorities and commitments, including those referred to in the communications of the Commission of 11 December 2019 on the European Green Deal. The SIA should also include an indicative financial plan covering the period 2021-2027. It should also include an estimate of financial needs and sources for the future activities of the relevant multiannual financial framework (MFF). It should also include an indicative financial plan covering the period of the relevant multiannual financial framework (MFF). FROM WHEN DOES THE DECISION APPLY? It has applied since 20 May 2021. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Strategic Innovation Agenda of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) (European Commission). KEY TERMS Strategic Innovation Agenda: a set of priorities for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) for the period 2021-2027. MAIN DOCUMENT Decision (EU) 2021/820 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 20 May 2021 on the Strategic Innovation Agenda of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) 2021-2027: Boosting the Innovation Talent and Capacity of Europe and repealing Decision No 1312/2013/EU (OJ L 189, 28.5.2021, pp. 91-92) Successive amendments to Decision (EU) 2021/820 have been incorporated in the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Aromatised wine products — definition, description, presentation, labelling and protection of geographical indications Aromatised wine products — definition, description, presentation, labelling and protection of geographical indications SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 251/2014 on the definition, description, presentation, labelling and the protection of geographical indications of aromatised wine products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It updates the rules applicable to the definition, description, presentation, labelling and protection of geographical indications of certain aromatised wine products, while taking into account traditional production methods. Fishing opportunities for certain fish stocks and groups of fish stocks Fishing opportunities for certain fish stocks and groups of fish stocks SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2020/123 fixing for 2020 the fishing opportunities for certain fish stocks and groups of fish stocks, applicable in EU waters and, for Union fishing vessels, in certain non-Union waters WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the total allowable catches (TACs) for certain fish stocks and groups of fish stocks for the period from 1 January 2020 to 31 December 2024. KEY POINTS The TACs are based on available scientific and technical advice, taking into account biological and socio-economic aspects whilst ensuring fair treatment between fishing sectors, as well as in the light of the opinions expressed during the consultation of stakeholders, in particular at the meetings of the advisory councils. The total allowable catches (TACs) for certain fish stocks and groups of fish stocks are based on available scientific and technical advice, taking into account biological and socio-economic aspects whilst ensuring fair treatment between fishing sectors, as well as in the light of the opinions expressed during the consultation of stakeholders, in particular at the meetings of the advisory councils. The total allowable catches (TACs) for certain fish stocks and groups of fish stocks are based on available scientific and technical advice, taking into account biological and socio-economic aspects whilst ensuring fair treatment between fishing sectors, as well as in the light of the opinions expressed during the consultation of stakeholders, in particular at the meetings of the advisory councils. Decision (EU) 2022/313 and Decision (EU) 2020/701 provide macro-financial assistance to Ukraine in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. Decision (EU) 2020/701 provided EUR 1,2 billion in loans to Ukraine and was completed in September 2021. Decision (EU) 2022/313 and Decision (EU) 2020/701 provide loans to Ukraine in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. It establishes a multiannual recovery plan for Mediterranean swordfish (Xiphias gladius) for the period 2017–2031. KEY POINTS The EU is a party to the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) Convention. European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF) European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/1139 establishing the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund and amending Regulation (EU) 2017/1004 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Maritime, Fisheries and Aquaculture Fund (EMFAF) for the period from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2027. KEY POINTS The EMFAF is part of the European Union’s (EU’s) multiannual financial framework (MFF 2021-2027). It aims to support the EU’s common fisheries policy (CFP), the EU’s maritime policy and the EU’s international commitments in the field of ocean governance. The EMFAF’s main objectives are to: protect and conserve marine biological resources, for food security through the supply of seafood products, for the growth of a sustainable blue economy and for healthy, safe, secure, clean and managed seas and oceans; support the EU’s international commitments in the field of ocean governance. The EMFAF’s budget The EMFAF’s budget is set out in Regulation (EU) 2021/1139, which lays down the priorities of the EMFAF, its budget and the specific rules for providing EU funding, complementing the general rules applicable to the EMFAF under Regulation (EU) 2021/1060 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The EMFAF’s main objectives are to: protect and conserve marine biological resources, for food security through the supply of seafood products, for the growth of a sustainable blue economy and for healthy, safe, secure, clean and managed seas and oceans; support the EU’s international commitments in the field of ocean governance. The EMFAF’s budget is set out in Regulation (EU) 2021/1139, which lays down the priorities of the EMFAF, its budget and the specific rules for providing EU funding, complementing the general rules applicable to the EMFAF under Regulation (EU) 2021/1060 of the European Parliament and of the Council. Management, conservation and control measures applicable in the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Convention area Management, conservation and control measures applicable in the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Convention area SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2021/56 laying down management, conservation and control measures applicable in the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Convention area and amending Council Regulation (EC) No 520/2007 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down management, conservation and control measures applicable in the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Convention area. KEY POINTS The Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) has the authority to adopt decisions (‘Resolutions’) to ensure the long-term conservation and sustainable use of the fishery resources in the convention area. These decisions are essentially addressed to the contracting parties to the convention, but also contain obligations for private operators (e.g. masters of vessels). The IATTC is responsible for the long-term conservation and sustainable use of the fishery resources in the convention area. The IATTC is also responsible for coordinating the implementation of the International Dolphin Conservation Programme (IDCP), which is to have an integral role in coordinating the measures that will be taken within the framework of the convention area. Regulation (EU) 2021/56 lays down management, conservation and control measures applicable in the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Convention area and amending Council Regulation (EC) No 520/2007. Better law-making: Interinstitutional agreement Better law-making: Interinstitutional agreement SUMMARY OF: Interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission on better law-making WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE INTERINSTITUTIONAL AGREEMENT? The Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making aims to ensure that EU legislation is as simple and as clear as possible, avoids overregulation and administrative burdens for citizens, administrations and businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and is designed to facilitate its transposition and practical application and to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the EU economy. It complements the Treaty on European Union (TEU) on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. KEY POINTS The Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making complements the Treaty on European Union (TEU) on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. It aims to ensure that EU legislation is as simple and as clear as possible, avoids overregulation and administrative burdens for citizens, administrations and businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and is designed to facilitate its transposition and practical application and to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the EU economy. The Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making complements the Treaty on European Union (TEU) on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. It complements the Treaty on European Union (TEU) on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. The Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making complements the Treaty on European Union (TEU) on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. European citizens’ initiative European citizens’ initiative SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 211/2011 on the citizens’ initiative WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the procedures and conditions for European Union (EU) citizens to support a citizens’ initiative. KEY POINTS The European Union (EU) strengthens citizenship of the EU and enhances further the democratic functioning of the Union by providing, inter alia, that every citizen is to have the right to participate in the democratic life of the Union by way of a European citizens’ initiative. That procedure affords citizens the possibility of directly approaching the Commission with a request inviting it to submit a proposal for a legal act of the Union for the purpose of implementing the Treaties similar to the right conferred on the European Parliament under Article 225 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and on the Council under Article 241 TFEU. That procedure affords citizens the possibility of directly approaching the Commission with a request inviting it to submit a proposal for a legal act of the Union for the purpose of implementing the Treaties similar to the right conferred on the European Parliament under Article 225 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and on the Council under Article 241 TFEU. The procedures and conditions required for the citizens’ initiative should be clear, simple, user-friendly and proportionate to the nature of the citizens’ initiative so as to encourage participation by citizens and to make the Union more accessible. They should strike a judicious balance between rights and obligations. They should also ensure that citizens of the Union are subject to similar conditions for supporting a citizens’ initiative regardless of the Member State from which they come. The European Commission is empowered to provide citizens with information and informal advice about citizens’ initiatives, notably as regards the registration criteria. It should, upon request, provide citizens with information and informal advice about citizens’ initiatives, notably as regards the registration criteria. That procedure affords citizens the possibility of directly approaching the Commission with a request inviting it to submit a proposal for a legal act of the Union for the purpose of implementing the Treaties similar to the right conferred on the European Parliament under Article 225 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and on the Council under Article 241 TFEU. That procedure affords citizens the possibility of directly approaching the Commission with a request inviting it to submit a proposal for a legal act of the Union for the purpose of implementing the Treaties similar to the right conferred on the European Parliament under Article 225 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and on the Council under Article 241 TFEU. The procedure affords citizens the possibility of directly approaching the Commission with a request inviting it to submit a proposal for a legal act of the Union for the purpose of implementing the Treaties similar to the right conferred on the European Parliament under Article 225 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and on the Council under Article 241 TFEU. That procedure affords citizens the possibility of directly approaching the Commission with a request inviting it to submit a proposal for a legal act of the Union for the purpose of implementing the Treaties similar to the right conferred on the European Parliament under Article 225 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and on the Council under Article 241 TFEU. The procedure affords citizens the possibility of directly approaching the Commission with a request inviting it to submit a proposal for a legal act of the Union for the purpose of implementing the Treaties similar to the right conferred on the European Parliament under Article 225 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and on the Council under Article 241 TFEU. The procedure affords citizens the possibility of directly approaching the Commission with a request inviting it to submit a proposal for a legal act of the Union for the purpose of implementing the Treaties similar to the right conferred on the European Parliament under Article 225 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and on the Council under Article 241 TFEU. The procedure affords citizens the possibility of directly approaching the Commission with a request inviting it to submit a proposal for a legal act of the Union for the purpose of implementing the Treaties similar to the right conferred on the European Parliament under Article 225 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) and on the Council under Article 241 TFEU. Statistics on sales and use of pesticides Statistics on sales and use of pesticides SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1185/2009 — statistics on pesticides WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to harmonise and up-to-date statistics on the sale and use of pesticides in the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS The regulation applies to pesticides which are plant protection products covered by Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 October 2009 concerning the placing of plant protection products on the market. It does not apply to pesticides which are biocidal products (i.e. active substances for use in biocidal products). The regulation requires EU countries to collect data on the sale and use of pesticides in order to assess the impact of pesticides on human health and the environment and to calculate relevant indicators on the risks for health and the environment related to pesticide use. EU countries must collect data on the sale and use of pesticides in order to assess the impact of pesticides on human health and the environment and to calculate relevant indicators on the risks for health and the environment related to pesticide use. Placing of plant protection products on the market Placing of plant protection products on the market SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1107/2009 — placing of plant protection products on the market and repealing Directives 79/117/EEC and 91/414/EEC WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules on the placing on the market and use of plant protection products containing certain active substances. It repeals Directives 79/117/EEC and 91/414/EEC. KEY POINTS EU countries must ensure that plant protection products containing certain active substances do not have any harmful effects on human or animal health or on the environment. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) performs a risk assessment on the safety of plant protection products before they can be placed on the market. The EFSA performs a risk assessment on the safety of plant protection products containing certain active substances before they can be placed on the market. Internal Market Information System (IMI) Internal Market Information System (IMI) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1024/2012 on administrative cooperation through the Internal Market Information System WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the functioning of the internal market by providing an effective, user-friendly tool for the implementation of administrative cooperation between Member States and between Member States and the European Commission. It repeals Commission Decision 2008/49/EC. KEY POINTS IMI is a software application accessible via the internet, developed by the Commission in cooperation with the Member States, in order to assist Member States with the practical implementation of information exchange requirements laid down in EU acts by providing a centralised communication mechanism to facilitate cross-border exchange of information and mutual assistance. IMI helps competent authorities to identify their counterpart in another Member State, to manage the exchange of information, including personal data, on the basis of simple and unified procedures and to overcome language barriers on the basis of pre-defined and pre-translated workflows. Where available, the Commission should provide IMI users with any existing additional translation functionality that meets their needs, is compatible with the security and confidentiality requirements for the exchange of information in IMI and can be offered at a reasonable cost. The Commission supplies IMI users with any existing additional translation functionality that meets their needs, is compatible with the security and confidentiality requirements for the exchange of information in IMI and can be offered at a reasonable cost. Management measures for the sustainable exploitation of fishery resources in the Mediterranean Sea Management measures for the sustainable exploitation of fishery resources in the Mediterranean Sea SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1343/2011 on certain provisions for fishing in the GFCM (General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean) Agreement area and amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1967/2006 concerning management measures for the sustainable exploitation of fishery resources in the Mediterranean Sea WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to implement the recommendations of the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM) for the sustainable exploitation of fishery resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea. KEY POINTS The GFCM agreement covers the entire GFCM area, which is the Mediterranean and the Black Sea and connecting waters, as defined in Council Decision 98/416/EC of 16 June 1998 on the accession of the European Community to the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM). The GFCM agreement provides an appropriate framework for multilateral cooperation to promote the development, conservation, rational management and best utilisation of living marine resources in the Mediterranean and the Black Sea at levels which are considered sustainable and at low risk of collapse. The GFCM agreement covers the entire GFCM area, which is the Mediterranean and the Black Sea and connecting waters, as defined in Council Decision 98/416/EC of 16 June 1998 on the accession of the European Community to the General Fisheries Commission for the Mediterranean (GFCM). Unitary patent protection Unitary patent protection SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1257/2012 implementing enhanced cooperation in the area of the creation of unitary patent protection Decision 2011/167/EU authorising enhanced cooperation in the area of the creation of unitary patent protection Regulation (EU) No 1257/2012 implementing enhanced cooperation in the area of the creation of unitary patent protection WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION AND OF THE DECISION? Unitary patent protection (UPP) is a legal instrument that provides patent protection throughout the European Union (EU). It is the result of enhanced cooperation between Belgium, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Ireland, Greece, France, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Hungary, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovenia, Slovakia, Finland, Sweden and the United Kingdom. The decision authorising enhanced cooperation between Belgium, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Ireland, Greece, France, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Hungary, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovenia, Slovakia, Finland, Sweden and the United Kingdom (now the United Kingdom) was adopted on 10 March 2011. The decision authorising enhanced cooperation between Belgium, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Ireland, Greece, France, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Hungary, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovenia, Slovakia, Finland, Sweden and the United Kingdom (now the United Kingdom) was adopted on 17 December 2012. The decision authorising enhanced cooperation between Belgium, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Ireland, Greece, France, Cyprus, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Hungary, Malta, the Netherlands, Austria, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovenia, Slovakia, Finland, Sweden and the United Kingdom (now the United Kingdom) was adopted on 17 December 2012. European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 386/2012 on entrusting the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (Trade Marks and Designs) with tasks related to the enforcement of intellectual property rights WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up the European Observatory on Infringements of Intellectual Property Rights (OIPR) to gather, monitor and report information and data related to all infringements of intellectual property rights in the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS The OIR is a network of experts from the public and private sectors and is managed by the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (Trade Marks and Designs). Its main tasks are to gather, monitor and report information and data related to all infringements of intellectual property rights in the EU and to exchange best practices and expertise on the enforcement of intellectual property rights in the EU. The OIR is the central resource for gathering, monitoring and reporting information and data related to all infringements of intellectual property rights in the EU. The OIR is a network of experts from the public and private sectors and is managed by the Office for Harmonization in the Internal Market (Trade Marks and Designs). Summary 94:
Exercise of the EU’s rights under international trade rules Exercise of the EU’s rights under international trade rules SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 654/2014 concerning the exercise of the EU’s rights for the application and enforcement of international trade rules WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure the effective exercise of the EU’s rights under international trade agreements in order to safeguard its economic interests. KEY POINTS The EU has concluded a number of multilateral, regional and bilateral international trade agreements creating rights and obligations for the mutual benefit of the parties. It is essential that the EU possess appropriate instruments to ensure the effective exercise of the EU’s rights under international trade agreements in order to safeguard its economic interests. It is particularly the case in enforcing situations where third countries enact trade restrictive measures that diminish the benefits accruing to the EU’s economic operators under international trade agreements. This is particularly the case in enforcing situations where third countries enact trade restrictive measures that diminish the benefits accruing to the EU’s economic operators under international trade agreements. WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 July 2014. BACKGROUND For more information, see: ‘International trade rules’ on the European Commission's website. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) No 654/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 May 2014 concerning the exercise of the Union's rights for the application and enforcement of international trade rules and amending Council Regulation (EC) No 3286/94 laying down Community procedures in the field of the common commercial policy in order to ensure the exercise of the Community's rights under international trade rules, in particular those established under the auspices of the World Trade Organization (OJ L 189, 27.6.2014, pp. 50–57) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) No 654/2014 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. It lays down the most appropriate procedures to guarantee the effective application of the bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for bananas of the Agreement establishing an Association between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Central America on the other. KEY POINTS The bilateral safeguard clause and the stabilisation mechanism for bananas of the Agreement establishing an Association between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and Central America on the other are designed to prevent serious harm to the EU banana growing sector which is of great importance to the agricultural producers of many of the outermost regions of the Union. The agreement was signed on 29 June 2012, received the consent of the European Parliament and the Council on 11 December 2012 and is to apply as provided for in Article 353 of the agreement. EU external sea borders — rules for border surveillance EU external sea borders — rules for border surveillance SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 656/2014 establishing rules for the surveillance of the external sea borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes rules for border surveillance operations carried out by Member States at their external sea borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Eurosur). KEY POINTS The regulation applies to border surveillance operations carried out by Member States at their external sea borders in the context of operational cooperation coordinated by the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union (Eurosur). Border surveillance is not limited to the detection of attempts at border crossings but equally extends to steps such as intercepting vessels suspected of trying to gain entry to the EU without submitting to border checks, as well as arrangements intended to address situations such as search and rescue that may arise during a border surveillance operation at sea and arrangements intended to bring such an operation to a successful conclusion. Member States must cooperate with the competent authorities of non-EU countries in the context of border surveillance operations. Member States must respect the fundamental rights of migrants, including the fundamental right to information and analysis concerning those operations. Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 514/2014 laying down general provisions on the Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund and on the instrument for financial support for police cooperation, preventing and combating crime, and crisis management WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down general provisions on the EU’s Asylum, Migration and Integration Fund (AMIF) and on the instrument for financial support for police cooperation, preventing and combating crime, and crisis management. KEY POINTS The AMIF is designed to support the development of an area of freedom, security and justice in the European Union (EU). It is based on the principle of solidarity and responsibility-sharing which is indispensable in responding to the common challenges of the EU’s home affairs policy. The AMIF is designed to support the development of an area of freedom, security and justice: an area without internal borders where people may enter, move, live and work freely, confident that their rights are fully respected and their security assured, bearing in mind common challenges such as the development of a comprehensive EU immigration policy to enhance the competitiveness and social cohesion of the EU, the creation of a Common European Asylum System, the prevention of threats of serious and organised crime, and the fight against illegal immigration, human trafficking, cybercrime and terrorism. Conservation of fish stocks in relation to countries allowing non-sustainable fishing Conservation of fish stocks in relation to countries allowing non-sustainable fishing SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1026/2012 — measures for the purpose of the conservation of fish stocks in relation to countries allowing non-sustainable fishing WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules for the conservation of fish stocks in relation to countries allowing non-sustainable fishing. KEY POINTS The regulation defines the conditions under which a country can be considered to be a country allowing non-sustainable fishing. It sets out the types of measures that may be taken by the European Commission to prevent, deter and eliminate fishing activities that are environmentally sound, effective and proportionate to the conservation of a fishery involving a stock of common interest to that country and to the EU. It sets out the types of measures that may be taken by the Commission to prevent, deter and eliminate fishing activities that are environmentally sound, effective and proportionate to the conservation of a fishery involving a stock of common interest to that country and to the EU. Transitional arrangements for bilateral investment agreements between EU countries and non-EU countries Transitional arrangements for bilateral investment agreements between EU countries and non-EU countries SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1219/2012 — transitional arrangements for bilateral investment agreements between EU countries and non-EU countries WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out transitional arrangements for bilateral investment agreements between EU countries and non-EU countries. These transitional arrangements allow EU countries to continue to negotiate and conclude bilateral investment agreements with non-EU countries after the entry into force of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) on 1 January 2013. KEY POINTS EU countries may continue to negotiate and conclude bilateral investment agreements with non-EU countries after the entry into force of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) on 1 January 2013. Generalised system of preferences (GSP) Generalised system of preferences (GSP) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 978/2012 — applying a scheme of generalised tariff preferences WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the application of the EU’s generalised system of preferences (GSP) for the period from 1 January 2009 to 31 December 2015. It repeals Regulation (EC) No 732/2008. It replaces Regulation (EC) No 512/2011. KEY POINTS The EU’s generalised system of preferences (GSP) is designed to help developing countries reduce poverty and promote sustainable development. It is based on the principle of differential and more favourable treatment of developing countries, i.e. they share the same level of economic development as high-income or upper-middle income countries. Under the scheme, the EU provides generalised tariff preferences (GSPs) to developing countries which are classified as high-income or upper-middle income countries, i.e. they share the same level of economic development as high-income or upper-middle income countries. European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur) European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1052/2013 establishing the European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur). It aims to strengthen the exchange of information and the operational cooperation between national authorities of European Union (EU) countries as well as with the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the EU established by Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes the European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur). It aims to strengthen the exchange of information and the operational cooperation between national authorities of European Union (EU) countries as well as with the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the EU established by Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004. It establishes the European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur). It will provide those authorities and the Agency with the infrastructure and tools needed to improve their situational awareness and reaction capability at the external borders of the Member States of the EU for the purpose of detecting, preventing and combating illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contributing to ensuring the protection and saving the lives of migrants. The European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur) will improve the operational and technical capability of the Member States and the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union to detect, prevent and combat illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contribute to ensuring the protection and saving the lives of migrants. The European Border Surveillance System (Eurosur) will provide those authorities and the European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union with the infrastructure and tools needed to improve their situational awareness and reaction capability at the external borders of the Member States of the European Union for the purpose of detecting, preventing and combating illegal immigration and cross-border crime and contributing to ensuring the protection and saving the lives of migrants. Accelerated phasing-in of double-hull or equivalent design requirements for single-hull oil tankers Accelerated phasing-in of double-hull or equivalent design requirements for single-hull oil tankers SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 530/2012 on the accelerated phasing-in of double-hull or equivalent design requirements for single-hull oil tankers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It recasts Regulation (EC) No 417/2002 on the accelerated phasing-in of double-hull or equivalent design requirements for single-hull oil tankers. It aims to reduce the risk of accidents involving oil tankers and the associated pollution of the EU’s coast-lines and marine resources. KEY POINTS Regulation (EU) No 530/2012 repeals and replaces Regulation (EC) No 417/2002. It recasts Regulation (EC) No 417/2002 on the accelerated phasing-in of double-hull or equivalent design requirements for single-hull oil tankers. It recasts Regulation (EU) No 530/2012 on the accelerated phasing-in of double-hull or equivalent design requirements for single-hull oil tankers. It recasts Regulation (EU) No 530/2012 on the accelerated phasing-in of double-hull or equivalent design requirements for single-hull oil tankers. It recasts Regulation (EU) No 530/2012 on the accelerated phasing-in of double-hull or equivalent design requirements for single-hull oil tankers. It recasts Regulation (EU) No 530/2012 on the accelerated phasing-in of double-hull or equivalent design requirements for single-hull oil tankers. European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1094/2010 establishing a European Supervisory Authority (European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (EIOPA) to supervise the insurance and occupational pension sectors in the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS EIOPA is one of three new European supervisory authorities set up in response to the financial crisis of 2007 and 2008. The other two are the European Banking Authority (EBA) and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA). EIOPA is the EU’s single supervisor for the insurance and occupational pension sectors. EIOPA is the EU’s single supervisor for the insurance and occupational pension sectors. EIOPA is the EU’s single supervisor for the insurance and occupational pension sectors. Substances that deplete the ozone layer Substances that deplete the ozone layer SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1005/2009 on substances that deplete the ozone layer WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It repeals and replaces Regulation (EC) No 2037/2000 on substances that deplete the ozone layer. KEY POINTS Substances that deplete the ozone layer Substances that deplete the ozone layer are greenhouse gases but are not controlled under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and its Kyoto Protocol on the assumption that the Protocol will phase out ozone-depleting substances (ODS). Many ODS are greenhouse gases but are not controlled under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and its Kyoto Protocol on the assumption that the Protocol will phase out ODS. However, the task of phasing out ODS still needs to be completed in the European Union and globally, whilst bearing in mind that at present many alternatives to ODS have a high global warming potential. The European Environment Agency and the European Environment Information and Observation Network The European Environment Agency and the European Environment Information and Observation Network SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 401/2009 on the European Environment Agency and the European Environment Information and Observation Network WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It codifies Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 on the establishment of the European Environment Agency and the European Environment Information and Observation Network. KEY POINTS The European Environment Agency (EEA) and the European Environment Information and Observation Network (EEION) collect, process and analyse environmental data at European level to provide objective, reliable and comparable information which will enable the European Union (EU) and the EU countries to take the necessary measures to protect the environment, to assess the results of such measures and to ensure that the public is properly informed about the state of the environment. EEA and EEION cooperate with existing structures at Community level to enable the European Commission to ensure full application of Community legislation on the environment. EEA and EEION cooperate with existing structures at Community level to enable the Commission to ensure full application of Community legislation on the environment. Eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS): voluntary participation Eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS): voluntary participation SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1221/2009 on the voluntary participation by organisations in a Community eco-management and audit scheme WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to encourage more organisations to participate in the European Union’s eco-management and audit scheme (EMAS). It repeals Regulation (EC) No 761/2001 and Commission Decisions 2001/681/EC and 2006/193/EC. KEY POINTS Organisations wishing to participate in EMAS must submit an application to the competent authority of the European Union (EU) Member State in which they are located. The application must contain the following information: the name and address of the organisation; the number of employees and workers; a description of the organisation’s activities and its environmental performance; Civil aviation security: common rules Civil aviation security: common rules SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 300/2008 on common rules in the field of civil aviation security WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down common rules to protect civil aviation against acts of unlawful interference*. It repeals and replaces Regulation (EC) No 2320/2002 on civil aviation security. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to airports serving civil aviation located in the territory of an EU country, to entities providing goods and/or services to or through such airports and to operators providing services at such airports and to aircraft registered in a non-EU country. It does not apply to aircraft registered in a non-EU country or to aircraft registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country. It does not apply to aircraft registered in a non-EU country or to aircraft registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country. It does not apply to aircraft registered in a non-EU country or to aircraft registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country. It does not apply to aircraft registered in a non-EU country or to aircraft registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country. It does not apply to aircraft registered in a non-EU country or to aircraft registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country. It does not apply to aircraft registered in a non-EU country or to aircraft registered in a non-EU country registered in a non-EU country. It does not apply to aircraft registered in a non-EU country or to aircraft registered in a non-EU country. It does not apply to aircraft registered in a non-EU country or to aircraft registered in a non-EU country. It does not apply to aircraft registered in a non-EU country or to aircraft registered in a non-EU country. It does not apply to aircraft registered in a non-EU country or to aircraft registered in a non-EU country. It does not apply to aircraft registered in a non-EU country or to aircraft registered in a non-EU country. Restrictive measures against serious human rights violations and abuses Restrictive measures against serious human rights violations and abuses SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2020/1998 concerning restrictive measures against serious human rights violations and abuses Decision (CFSP) 2020/1999 concerning restrictive measures against serious human rights violations and abuses WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATIONS? Regulation (EU) 2020/1998 establishes a framework for targeted restrictive measures to address serious human rights violations and abuses worldwide. Decision (CFSP) 2020/1999 establishes a framework for targeted restrictive measures to address serious human rights violations and abuses worldwide. Decision (CFSP) 2020/1999 provides for the freezing of funds and economic resources of, and the prohibition to make funds and economic resources available to, natural or legal persons, entities or bodies responsible for, providing support to or otherwise involved in serious human rights violations or abuses, as well as those associated with the natural and legal persons, entities and bodies covered. Regulation (EU) 2020/1998 sets out the list of natural and legal persons, entities and bodies whose funds and economic resources are to be frozen in accordance with Decision (CFSP) 2020/1999. KEY POINTS The list of natural and legal persons, entities and bodies whose funds and economic resources are to be frozen in accordance with Regulation (EU) 2020/1998 is set out in Annex I to Decision (CFSP) 2020/1999. EUNAVFOR MED IRINI — military operation in the Mediterranean (EUNAVFOR MED IRINI) EUNAVFOR MED IRINI — military operation in the Mediterranean (EUNAVFOR MED IRINI) SUMMARY OF: Decision (CFSP) 2020/472 on a European Union military operation in the Mediterranean (EUNAVFOR MED IRINI) WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DECISION? It authorises EUNAVFOR MED IRINI to contribute to the implementation of United Nations Security Council (UNSC) measures to prevent the illicit export of petroleum from Libya, to capacity building and training of the Libyan Coast Guard and Navy, and to the disruption of the business model of human smuggling and trafficking networks. KEY POINTS EUNAVFOR MED IRINI is a European Union (EU) military operation in the Mediterranean. It operates under the Political and Security Committee (PSC) and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. EUNAVFOR MED IRINI has been operational since 18 May 2015, and was extended through Council Decision (CFSP) 2019/1595 on 17 February 2020. EUNAVFOR MED IRINI is a political agreement between the EU and Libya to implement the UN arms embargo on Libya by using aerial, satellite and maritime assets. The decision authorises EUNAVFOR MED IRINI to contribute to the implementation of United Nations (UN) measures to prevent the illicit export of petroleum from Libya, to capacity building and training of the Libyan Coast Guard and Navy, and to the disruption of the business model of human smuggling and trafficking networks. European Image Archiving System on False and Authentic Documents Online (FADO) European Image Archiving System on False and Authentic Documents Online (FADO) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2020/493 on the European Image Archiving System on False and Authentic Documents Online (FADO) system and repealing Council Joint Action 98/700/JHA WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up the European Image Archiving System on False and Authentic Documents Online (FADO) to facilitate the exchange of information on authentic documents and on known methods of falsification between EU countries. It repeals Joint Action 98/700/JHA. KEY POINTS The FADO system provides for the electronic storage, rapid exchange and validation of information on authentic and false documents. It is a multi-purpose tool for the application of the Schengen acquis. It contributes to maintaining a high level of security within the EU by supporting police, border guard and other law enforcement authorities of the Member States in the fight against document fraud, in particular at the external borders. Regulation (EU) 2020/493 repeals Joint Action 98/700/JHA. It replaces Joint Action 98/700/JHA with Regulation (EU) 2019/1896. The FADO system is a multi-purpose tool for the application of the Schengen acquis. It provides for the electronic storage, rapid exchange and validation of information on authentic and false documents. It is a multi-purpose tool for the application of the Schengen acquis. It contributes to maintaining a high level of security within the EU by supporting police, border guard and other law enforcement authorities of the Member States in the fight against document fraud, in particular at the external borders. Regulation (EU) 2020/493 repeals Joint Action 98/700/JHA. It replaces Joint Action 98/700/JHA with Regulation (EU) 2019/1896. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 6 April 2020. BACKGROUND For more information, see: European Image Archiving System on False and Authentic Documents Online (FADO) on the European Commission's website. MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) 2020/493 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 30 March 2020 on the False and Authentic Documents Online (FADO) system and repealing Council Joint Action 98/700/JHA (OJ L 107, 6.4.2020, pp. 1-8) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) 2020/493 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Principles of non-discrimination and proportionality Principles of non-discrimination and proportionality SUMMARY OF: Directive (EU) 2018/958 on a proportionality test before adoption of new regulation of professions WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE DIRECTIVE? It aims to ensure that European Union (EU) Member States do not impose unjustified or disproportionate requirements on access to, or the pursuit of, a regulated profession. KEY POINTS Scope The directive applies to all professions, including those covered by Directive 2005/36/EC on professional education and training. It does not apply to professions which fall within the scope of Directive 2005/36/EC or which are regulated by a separate act. It does not apply to professions which do not fall within the scope of Directive 2005/36/EC or which are regulated by a separate act. The directive does not apply to professions which fall within the scope of Directive 2005/36/EC or which are regulated by a separate act. Scope The directive applies to all professions, including those covered by Directive 2005/36/EC or which are regulated by a separate act. It does not apply to professions which fall within the scope of Directive 2005/36/EC or which are regulated by a separate act. ACT Directive (EU) 2018/958 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 28 June 2018 on a proportionality test before adoption of new regulation of professions SUMMARY WHAT DOES THE DIRECTIVE DO? It does not apply to professions which fall within the scope of Directive 2005/36/EC or which are regulated by a separate act. It does not apply to professions which fall within the scope of Directive 2005/36/EC or which are regulated by a separate act. Management, conservation and control measures applicable in the South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (SPRFMO) Convention Area Management, conservation and control measures applicable in the South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (SPRFMO) Convention Area SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/975 laying down management, conservation and control measures applicable in the South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (SPRFMO) Convention Area WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down management, conservation and control measures applicable in the South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (SPRFMO) Convention Area. It aims to ensure that the conservation and management measures adopted by the SPRFMO are fully transposed into EU law and are, therefore, uniformly and effectively implemented within the EU. KEY POINTS The SPRFMO Convention Area covers the waters of the South Pacific Ocean. It is governed by the Convention on the Conservation and Management of High Seas Fishery Resources in the South Pacific Ocean (the SPRFMO Convention), which was approved by the United Nations General Assembly in 2012. Regulation (EU) 2018/1672 on controls on cash entering or leaving the EU Regulation (EU) 2018/1672 on controls on cash entering or leaving the EU SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/1672 on controls on cash entering or leaving the EU WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to prevent and detect money laundering and terrorist financing by laying down a system of controls applicable to natural persons who enter or leave the EU carrying amounts of cash or bearer instruments equal to or greater than EUR 10 000 or its equivalent in other currencies. It repeals Regulation (EC) No 1889/2005. KEY POINTS Regulation (EU) 2018/1672 applies to all persons who enter or leave the EU carrying amounts of cash or bearer instruments equal to or greater than EUR 10 000 or its equivalent in other currencies. It does not apply to the proceeds of criminal activities or terrorist activities defined in Article 32 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) or to the proceeds of terrorist activities defined in Article 355 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). Regulation (EU) 2018/1672 applies to all persons who enter or leave the EU carrying amounts of cash or bearer instruments equal to or greater than EUR 10 000 or its equivalent in other currencies. Summary 123:
Governance of the Energy Union and Climate Action Governance of the Energy Union and Climate Action SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2018/1999 on the governance of the Energy Union and Climate Action WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets up the governance of the Energy Union (EU) and the Climate Action (CAA) to ensure the achievement of the 2030 and long-term objectives and targets of the Energy Union in line with the 2015 Paris Agreement on climate change following the 21st Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (the ‘Paris Agreement’). It repeals Regulation (EU) No 525/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council and replaces it with Regulation (EU) 2018/1999, which replaces Regulation (EC) No 663/2009 and (EC) No 715/2009. KEY POINTS The regulation sets up the governance of the Energy Union and the Climate Action. The governance of the Energy Union and the Climate Action is governed by the European Parliament and the Council. The governance of the Energy Union and the Climate Action is governed by the European Parliament and the Council. Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) Persistent organic pollutants (POPs) SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2019/1021 on persistent organic pollutants WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to prohibit the manufacture, placing on the market and use of intentionally manufactured persistent organic pollutants (POPs)*. It repeals Regulation (EC) No 850/2004, which had been substantially amended several times. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to the manufacture, placing on the market and use of intentionally manufactured POPs. It does not apply to stockpiles*. It does not apply to stockpiles of substances used in the manufacture, placing on the market or use of intentionally manufactured POPs. Protection of EU trade marks Protection of EU trade marks SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/1001 on the European Union trade mark WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It codifies Regulation (EC) No 207/2009, which created a system of trade mark protection specific to the EU which provided for the protection of trade marks at the level of the EU, in parallel to the protection of trade marks available at the level of the Member States in accordance with the national trade mark systems, harmonised by Council Directive 89/104/EEC. KEY POINTS The EU trade mark is an indication of the goods or services of an undertaking to be distinguished by identical means throughout the whole of the EU, regardless of frontiers. It does not replace national laws on the recognition of the goods and services of an EU trade mark. The registration of a trade mark is governed by the laws of the EU Member States. Cross-border exchange of accessible format copies of certain works and other protected subject matter protected by copyright and related rights for the benefit of persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled Cross-border exchange of accessible format copies of certain works and other protected subject matter protected by copyright and related rights for the benefit of persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2017/1563 on the cross-border exchange between the EU and third countries of accessible format copies of certain works and other protected subject matter protected by copyright and related rights for the benefit of persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to facilitate the cross-border exchange between the EU and non-EU countries of accessible format copies of certain works and other protected subject matter protected by copyright and related rights for the benefit of persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled. KEY POINTS The Marrakesh Treaty to Facilitate Access to Published Works for Persons Who Are Blind, Visually Impaired, or Otherwise Print Disabled (the ‘Marrakesh Treaty’) was signed on behalf of the EU on 30 April 2014. It requires contracting parties to provide for exceptions or limitations to copyright and related rights for the making and dissemination of copies, in accessible formats, of certain works and other protected subject matter, and for the cross-border exchange of those copies. The Marrakesh Treaty applies to persons who are blind, visually impaired or otherwise print-disabled and to persons who have a visual impairment which cannot be improved so as to give them visual function substantially equivalent to that of a person who has no such impairment. The regulation applies to: e-books, newspapers, magazines and other printed material, including in Braille, large print and audio format copies, for non-commercial purposes within the EU and to persons who have a perceptual or reading disability, including dyslexia or any other learning disability preventing them from reading printed works to substantially the same degree as persons without such disability, and persons who are unable, due to a physical disability, to hold or manipulate a book or to focus or move the eyes to the extent that would be normally acceptable for reading, insofar as, as a result of such impairments or disabilities, those persons are unable to read printed works to substantially the same degree as persons without such impairments or disabilities. The regulation applies to: e-books, newspapers, magazines and other printed material, including in Braille, large print and audio format copies, for non-commercial purposes within the EU and to persons who have a perceptual or reading disability, including in Braille, large print and audio format copies, for non-commercial purposes within the EU and to persons who have a perceptual or reading disability, including in Braille, large print and audio format copies, for non-commercial purposes within the EU and to persons who have a visual impairment, including in Braille, large print Appliances burning gaseous fuels — repealing Directive 2009/142/EC Appliances burning gaseous fuels — repealing Directive 2009/142/EC SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) 2016/426 on appliances burning gaseous fuels and repealing Directive 2009/142/EC WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It repeals Directive 2009/142/EC on the placing on the market and the putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. It lays down rules for the placing on the market and the putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to all appliances, whether new or second-hand, intended for domestic or non-domestic use. It does not apply to appliances intended for exhibition or collection purposes, such as antique and other products. Manufacturers must ensure that their products comply with the essential requirements laid down in Annex I to the regulation. Annex II to the regulation sets out the essential requirements for the placing on the market and the putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. Annex III sets out the essential requirements for the placing on the market and the putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. Annex IV sets out the essential requirements for the placing on the market and the putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. Annex V sets out the essential requirements for the placing on the market and the putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. Annex VI sets out the essential requirements for the placing on the market and the putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. Annex VII sets out the essential requirements for the placing on the market and the putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. Annex VIII sets out the essential requirements for the placing on the market and the putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. Annex IX sets out the essential requirements for the placing on the market and the putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. Annex X sets out the essential requirements for the placing on the market and the putting into service of appliances burning gaseous fuels. Professional cross-border transport of euro cash by road between euro-area countries Professional cross-border transport of euro cash by road between euro-area countries SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1214/2011 on the professional cross-border transport of euro cash by road between euro-area countries WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules for the professional cross-border transport of euro cash by road between euro-area countries. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to cash-in-transit (CIT) companies that transport euro banknotes and coins between participating EU countries. Food information — EU rules Food information — EU rules SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 on the provision of food information to consumers WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure that consumers are informed as regards the content and presentation of food they consume. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to all foods, whether prepacked or ready-to-eat, which are sold in the European Union (EU). It repeals Directive 87/250/EEC, Council Directive 90/496/EEC, Commission Directive 1999/10/EC, Commission Directive 2000/13/EC, Commission Directives 2002/67/EC and 2008/5/EC and Commission Regulation (EC) No 608/2004. It replaces Directives 90/496/EEC, 1999/10/EC, 2000/13/EC, Commission Directives 2002/67/EC and 2008/5/EC and Commission Regulation (EC) No 608/2004. The regulation applies to all foods, whether prepacked or ready-to-eat, which are sold in the European Union (EU). It repeals Directive 87/250/EEC, Council Directive 90/496/EEC, Commission Directive 1999/10/EC, Commission Directive 2000/13/EC, Commission Directives 2002/67/EC and 2008/5/EC and Commission Regulation (EC) No 608/2004. It replaces Directives 90/496/EEC, 1999/10/EC, Commission Directives 2002/67/EC and 2008/5/EC and Commission Regulation (EC) No 608/2004. The regulation applies to all foods, whether prepacked or ready-to-eat, which are sold in the European Union (EU). It repeals Directive 87/250/EEC, Council Directive 90/496/EEC, Commission Directive 1999/10/EC, Commission Directive 2000/13/EC, Commission Directives 2002/67/EC and 2008/5/EC and Commission Regulation (EC) No 608/2004. It replaces Directives 90/496/EEC, 1999/10/EC, Commission Directives 2002/67/EC and 2008/5/EC and Commission Regulation (EC) No 608/2004. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2012. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Food labelling (European Commission). This consolidated version is of documentary value only. It establishes uniform rules and a uniform procedure for the resolution of credit institutions and certain investment firms in the framework of a Single Resolution Mechanism and a Single Resolution Fund. KEY POINTS The regulation establishes a single resolution mechanism (SSM) and a single resolution fund (SDRF) for the resolution of credit institutions and certain investment firms in the European Union (EU). The SSM and the SDRF are based on the European Banking Authority (EBA), the European Central Bank (ECB) and the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA). It lays down rules on the recognition and enforcement of judgments issued in cross-border insolvency proceedings and on the coordination of insolvency proceedings which relate to the same debtor or to several members of the same group of companies. Admission to the occupation of road transport operator Admission to the occupation of road transport operator SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 — common rules concerning the conditions to be complied with to pursue the occupation of road transport operator WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out common rules concerning the conditions to be complied with to pursue the occupation of road transport operator. It repeals Directive 96/26/EC on admission to the occupation of road haulage operator and road passenger transport operator. KEY POINTS Admission to the occupation of road transport operator Admission to the occupation of road haulage operator and road passenger transport operator must be made in accordance with the conditions laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 on admission to the occupation of road haulage operator and road passenger transport operator. Admission to the occupation of road haulage operator must be made in accordance with the conditions laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 on admission to the occupation of road passenger transport operator. Admission to the occupation of road passenger transport operator must be made in accordance with the conditions laid down in Regulation (EC) No 1071/2009 on admission to the occupation of road passenger transport operator. Rules on the coordination of social security systems Rules on the coordination of social security systems SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 987/2009 laying down the procedure for implementing Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 on the coordination of social security systems WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATIONS? Regulation (EC) No 987/2009 lays down the procedures for implementing Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 on the coordination of social security systems. Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 modernises the rules on the coordination of Member States’ social security systems, specifying the measures and procedures for implementing them and simplifying them for all the players involved. Regulation (EC) No 987/2009 lays down the procedures for implementing Regulation (EC) No 883/2004 on the coordination of social security systems. EU statistics on public health and health and safety at work EU statistics on public health and health and safety at work SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1338/2008 on Community statistics on public health and health and safety at work WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to harmonise EU statistics on public health and health and safety at work. KEY POINTS EU statistics on public health and health and safety at work are compiled by Eurostat, the statistical office of the European Union (EU). These statistics are used to assess the impact and effectiveness of policies on health and safety at work and to respond to the specific needs of women and people with disabilities. EU countries are required to collect comparable data on accidents at work and occupational illnesses in order to make an objective assessment of the impact and effectiveness of the measures taken under the new Community strategy on health and safety at work (2007-2012). EU countries are required to collect comparable data on accidents at work and occupational illnesses in order to make an objective assessment of the impact and effectiveness of the measures taken under the new Community strategy on health and safety at work (2007-2012). Quarterly statistics on job vacancies Quarterly statistics on job vacancies SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 453/2008 on quarterly statistics on job vacancies WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the production of quarterly statistics on job vacancies* in the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS The European Commission and the European Central Bank (ECB) monitor short-term changes in job vacancies to monitor short-term changes in the level and structure of labour demand. The regulation sets out the rules for the production of quarterly statistics on job vacancies in the European Union (EU). Hydrogen-powered motor vehicles Hydrogen-powered motor vehicles SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 79/2009 on type-approval of hydrogen-powered motor vehicles WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down the technical requirements for the type-approval of hydrogen-powered motor vehicles. It is a separate regulation for the purposes of the Community type-approval procedure provided for by Directive 2007/46/EC establishing a framework for the approval of motor vehicles and their trailers, and of systems, components and separate technical units intended for such vehicles (Framework Directive). KEY POINTS The regulation lays down only fundamental requirements for the type-approval of hydrogen systems and components, whereas the technical specifications should be laid down by implementing measures adopted in accordance with Council Decision 1999/468/EC of 28 June 1999 laying down the procedures for the exercise of implementing powers conferred on the Commission. The Commission is empowered to establish the requirements and test procedures relating to new forms of hydrogen storage or usage, additional hydrogen components and the propulsion system. It is also empowered to establish specific procedures, tests and requirements with regard to the impact protection of hydrogen-powered vehicles and integrated system safety requirements. The regulation does not apply to vehicles powered by compressed natural gas (CNG) or liquefied natural gas (LNG). However, it does apply to hydrogen-powered vehicles powered by compressed natural gas (CNG) or liquefied natural gas (LNG). The regulation does not apply to vehicles powered by compressed natural gas (CNG) or liquefied natural gas (LNG). The Commission is empowered to establish specific procedures, tests and requirements with regard to the impact protection of hydrogen-powered vehicles and integrated system safety requirements. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. It establishes a procedure for the negotiation and conclusion of agreements between EU countries and non-EU countries on specific matters concerning the law applicable to contractual and non-contractual obligations. KEY POINTS EU countries must notify the European Commission of their intention to negotiate or conclude an agreement with a non-EU country on the same subject matter as an existing agreement between EU countries and non-EU countries on the same subject matter.
