Statutory audits of public-interest entities Statutory audits of public-interest entities SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 537/2014 on specific requirements regarding statutory audit of public-interest entities WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to improve the quality of statutory audits of public-interest entities (such as credit institutions, insurance undertakings, issuers of securities admitted to trading on a regulated market, payment institutions, undertakings for collective investment in transferable securities (UCITS), electronic money institutions and alternative investment funds) in order to enhance the degree of confidence of the public in the annual and consolidated financial statements of such entities. It repeals Commission Decision 2005/909/EC. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to: credit institutions, insurance undertakings, issuers of securities admitted to trading on a regulated market, payment institutions, undertakings for collective investment in transferable securities (UCITS), electronic money institutions and alternative investment funds. Statutory audits are carried out by one or more persons entitled to carry out such audits in accordance with EU law, namely: Article 1(1) of Council Directive 86/635/EEC; Article 1(1) of Council Directive 91/674/EEC; Article 4(4) of Directive 2004/109/EC; Article 15(2) of Directive 2007/64/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council; Article 73 of Directive 2009/65/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council; Common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products Common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1379/2013 on the common organisation of the markets in fishery and aquaculture products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules for the common organisation of the markets (CMO) for fishery and aquaculture products in the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS The CMO is an integral part of the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and should contribute to achieving its objectives. It aims to ensure that EU consumers are informed, through marketing and educational campaigns, of the value of eating fish and the wide variety of species available, as well as of the importance of understanding the information contained on labels. It is also necessary to ensure that consumers are informed, through marketing and educational campaigns, of the value of eating fish and the wide variety of species available, as well as of the importance of understanding the information contained on labels. Member States are responsible for the management of the CMO and for ensuring that it is implemented in line with the principles of good governance of the CFP. Member States are also responsible for ensuring that the CMO is implemented in line with the principles of fair competition and the application of social standards equivalent to those which apply to EU products. Member States are responsible for ensuring that the CMO is implemented in line with the principles of good governance of the CFP. Cohesion Fund — environment and trans-European transport infrastructure Cohesion Fund — environment and trans-European transport infrastructure SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1300/2013 on the Cohesion Fund and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1084/2006 WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It establishes the Cohesion Fund, which provides financial support to projects in the fields of environment and trans-European transport infrastructure. KEY POINTS The Cohesion Fund is a new framework for the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIFs). It aims to contribute to actions in pursuit of its environmental objectives, in accordance with Articles 11 and 191 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), namely energy efficiency and renewable energy and, in the transport sector outside the trans-European networks, rail, river and sea transport, intermodal transport systems and their interoperability, management of road, sea and air traffic, clean urban transport and public transport. The Cohesion Fund provides financial support to projects in the fields of environment and trans-European transport infrastructure. European territorial cooperation goal European territorial cooperation goal SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1299/2013 on specific provisions for the support from the European Regional Development Fund to the European territorial cooperation goal WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down specific provisions for the support from the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) to the European territorial cooperation goal. KEY POINTS The European territorial cooperation goal (ETC) aims to strengthen cooperation between regions located in different parts of the European Union (EU) and between regions located in different parts of the EU and non-EU countries. To achieve this goal, the ERDF supports cross-border cooperation between regions located in different parts of the EU and between regions located in different parts of the EU and non-EU countries. To achieve this goal, the ERDF supports cross-border cooperation between regions located in different parts of the EU and between regions located in different parts of the EU and non-EU countries. To achieve this goal, the ERDF supports cross-border cooperation between regions located in different parts of the EU and between regions located in different parts of the EU and non-EU countries. To achieve this goal, the ERDF supports cross-border cooperation between regions located in different parts of the EU and between regions located in different parts of the EU and non-EU countries. To achieve this goal, the ERDF supports cross-border cooperation between regions located in different parts of the EU and between regions located in different parts of the EU and non-EU countries. To achieve this goal, the ERDF supports cross-border cooperation between regions located in different parts of the EU and between regions located in different parts of the EU and non-EU countries. To achieve this goal, the ERDF supports cross-border cooperation between regions located in different parts of the EU and between regions located in different parts of the EU and non-EU countries. To achieve this goal, the ERDF supports cross-border cooperation between regions located in different parts of the EU and between regions located in different parts of the EU and non-EU countries. To achieve this goal, the ERDF supports cross-border cooperation between regions located in different parts of the EU and between regions located in different parts of the EU and non-EU countries. It aims to ensure that consumers have access to simple, efficient, fast and low-cost ways of resolving disputes arising from the sale of goods or the supply of services online in the European Union (EU). Direct payments to farmers under the common agricultural policy Direct payments to farmers under the common agricultural policy SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1307/2013 — rules for direct payments to farmers under support schemes within the framework of the common agricultural policy WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out rules for direct payments to farmers under the European Union’s (EU) common agricultural policy (CAP) from 1 January 2014. It repeals and replaces Regulation (EC) No 637/2008 and Council Regulation (EC) No 73/2009. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation covers all the main instruments of the European Union’s (EU’s) common agricultural policy (CAP), including the direct payment support schemes. It sets out rules for direct payments to farmers under the European Union’s (EU’s) common agricultural policy (CAP) from 1 January 2014. It repeals and replaces Regulation (EC) No 637/2008 and Council Regulation (EC) No 73/2009. It sets out rules for direct payments to farmers under the European Union’s (EU’s) common agricultural policy (CAP) from 1 January 2014. It repeals and replaces Regulation (EC) No 637/2008 and Council Regulation (EC) No 73/2009. It sets out rules for direct payments to farmers under the European Union’s (EU’s) common agricultural policy (CAP) from 1 January 2014. It repeals and replaces Regulation (EC) No 637/2008 and Council Regulation (EC) No 73/2009. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2014. It repeals and replaces Regulation (EC) No 1405/2006 on specific measures in the agricultural sector to remedy the difficulties caused by the particular geographical situation of the smaller Aegean islands. KEY POINTS The regulation sets out specific measures for agriculture in favour of the smaller Aegean islands and repeals Regulation (EC) No 1405/2006. These measures have been implemented by means of a support programme, which constitutes an essential tool for supplying those islands with agricultural products and for supporting local agricultural production. The regulation repeals Regulation (EC) No 1405/2006 and replaces it with Regulation (EU) No 229/2013. Statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road Statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 70/2012 on statistical returns in respect of the carriage of goods by road WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure comparable, reliable, synchronised, regular and comprehensive statistical data on the scale and development of the carriage of goods by road by means of vehicles registered in the EU, and on the degree of utilisation of vehicles carrying out this transport. KEY POINTS Each EU country must collect statistical data on the carriage of goods by road by means of vehicles registered in the EU and on the degree of utilisation of vehicles carrying out this transport. The data must be submitted to Eurostat, the statistical office of the European Union (EU). Each EU country must ensure a simultaneous, timely and appropriate transmission of individual data, once rendered anonymous, to the European Commission. The Commission must ensure a simultaneous, timely and appropriate transmission of individual data, once rendered anonymous, to the European Parliament and the Council. Each EU country must ensure a simultaneous, timely and appropriate transmission of individual data, once rendered anonymous, to the European Parliament and the Council. Service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters Service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1393/2007 on the service in the Member States of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to speed up the transmission and service of judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters between EU countries. It repeals Regulation (EC) No 1348/2000. KEY POINTS The regulation requires that judicial and extrajudicial documents in civil or commercial matters be transmitted directly and by rapid means between the EU countries’ local bodies designated by the EU countries to perform both functions. The local bodies designated by the EU countries to perform both functions are: the national courts of the EU country in which the proceedings are taking place; the national courts of the EU country in which the proceedings are taking place; Emissions from motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles Emissions from motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 715/2007 on type approval of motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 5 and Euro 6) and on access to vehicle repair and maintenance information WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down rules for the type approval of motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 5 and Euro 6) and on access to vehicle repair and maintenance information (OASIS). KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to all new light passenger and commercial vehicles registered in the European Union (EU) between 1 January 2007 and 31 December 2016. It does not apply to vehicles registered in non-EU countries. It does not apply to vehicles imported into the EU from non-EU countries. Type approval The regulation lays down rules for the type approval of motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 5 and Euro 6) and on access to vehicle repair and maintenance information (OASIS). Scope The regulation applies to all new light passenger and commercial vehicles registered in the European Union (EU) between 1 January 2007 and 31 December 2016. It does not apply to vehicles imported into the EU from non-EU countries. It does not apply to vehicles registered in the EU from non-EU countries. Type approval The regulation lays down rules for the type approval of motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 5 and Euro 6) and on access to vehicle repair and maintenance information (OASIS). Scope The regulation applies to all new light passenger and commercial vehicles registered in the European Union (EU) between 1 January 2007 and 31 December 2016. It does not apply to vehicles imported into the EU from non-EU countries. It does not apply to vehicles registered in the EU from non-EU countries. Type approval The regulation lays down rules for the type approval of motor vehicles with respect to emissions from light passenger and commercial vehicles (Euro 5 and Euro 6) and on access to vehicle repair and maintenance information (OASIS). It establishes a common authorisation procedure for food additives, food enzymes and food flavourings for use in and on foods in the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to food additives, food enzymes and food flavourings. It does not apply to food ingredients with flavouring properties for use in and on foods. Accreditation and market surveillance for the marketing of products Accreditation and market surveillance for the marketing of products SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 765/2008 — requirements for accreditation and market surveillance relating to the marketing of products WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the requirements for accreditation* and market surveillance* relating to the marketing of products in the European Union (EU). KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to the marketing of products for human, animal or plant health, safety and protection of consumers and of the environment. It does not apply to: drugs, medical devices, motor vehicles, aviation, agricultural products or chemicals. Accreditation EU countries must set up national accreditation bodies to carry out conformity assessments and market surveillance. These bodies must be accredited by the competent national authority of the EU country in which the product is registered. They must carry out conformity assessments and market surveillance in order to assess whether the product complies with the applicable Community harmonisation requirements. Market surveillance EU countries must set up national market surveillance bodies to carry out market surveillance in order to assess whether a product complies with the applicable Community harmonisation requirements. These bodies must be accredited by the competent national authority of the EU country in which the product is registered. They must carry out market surveillance in order to assess whether a product complies with the applicable Community harmonisation requirements. They must carry out market surveillance in order to assess whether a product complies with the applicable Community harmonisation requirements. They must carry out market surveillance in order to assess whether a product complies with the applicable Community harmonisation requirements. They must carry out market surveillance in order to assess whether a product complies with the applicable Community harmonisation requirements. They must carry out market surveillance in order to assess whether a product complies with the applicable Community harmonisation requirements. They must carry out market surveillance in order to assess whether a product complies with the applicable Community harmonisation requirements. They must carry out market surveillance in order to assess whether a product complies with the applicable Community harmonisation requirements. Summary 169:
Agreement between the EU and Iceland and Norway on the surrender procedure Agreement between the EU and Iceland and Norway on the surrender procedure SUMMARY OF: Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Iceland and the Kingdom of Norway on the surrender procedure WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE AGREEMENT AND OF THE DECISION? The agreement aims to improve judicial cooperation in criminal matters between the EU and Iceland and Norway, without prejudice to the rules protecting individual freedom. The decision approves the agreement on behalf of the EU. KEY POINTS The agreement aims to improve judicial cooperation in criminal matters between the EU and Iceland and Norway, without prejudice to the rules protecting individual freedom. Iceland and Norway are parties to a number of conventions in the field of extradition, including the European Convention on extradition of 13 December 1957 and the European Convention on the suppression of terrorism of 27 January 1977. The Nordic countries have uniform extradition laws with a common concept of extradition. The level of cooperation under the EU Convention of 10 March 1995 on simplified extradition procedure and of the EU Convention of 27 September 1996 relating to extradition should be maintained where it is not possible to increase it. Decisions on the execution of an arrest warrant as defined by this agreement must be subject to sufficient controls, which means that a judicial authority of the State where the requested person has been arrested should have to take the decision on his or her surrender. The role of central authorities in the execution of an arrest warrant as defined by this agreement should be limited to practical and administrative assistance. The agreement does not prevent a State from applying its constitutional rules relating to the protection of individuals with regard to fundamental rights and in particular the right to a fair trial. DATE OF ENTRY INTO FORCE The agreement entered into force on 21 October 2006. BACKGROUND For more information, see: Iceland and Norway (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENTS Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Iceland and the Kingdom of Norway on the surrender procedure between the Member States of the European Union and Iceland and Norway (OJ L 292, 21.10.2006, pp. 2-7) Council Decision 2006/308/EC of 21 October 2006 on the signing, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Iceland and the Kingdom of Norway on the surrender procedure between the Member States of the European Union and Iceland and Norway (OJ L 292, 21.10.2006, pp. 1-2) RELATED DOCUMENTS Regulation (EU) No Rail passengers’ rights and obligations Rail passengers’ rights and obligations SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 1371/2007 on rail passengers’ rights and obligations WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rights and obligations of rail passengers in the European Union (EU). It aims to improve the quality and effectiveness of rail passenger services in order to help increase the share of rail transport in relation to other modes of transport. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to all passengers travelling by rail in the EU, irrespective of their nationality, age or disability. It does not apply to passengers travelling by road, air or sea. It does not apply to passengers travelling by road, air or sea. Rights and obligations The regulation sets out the rights and obligations of rail passengers in the European Union (EU). It aims to improve the quality and effectiveness of rail passenger services in order to help increase the share of rail transport in relation to other modes of transport. It does not apply to passengers travelling by road, air or sea. Scope The regulation applies to all passengers travelling by rail in the EU, irrespective of their nationality, age or disability. It does not apply to passengers travelling by road, air or sea. It does not apply to passengers travelling by road, air or sea. WHAT DOES THE REGULATION DO? It sets out the rights and obligations of rail passengers in the European Union (EU). It aims to improve the quality and effectiveness of rail passenger services in order to help increase the share of rail transport in relation to other modes of transport. It applies to all passengers travelling by rail in the EU. It does not apply to passengers travelling by road, air or sea. Summary 173:
Rights of passengers in bus and coach transport Rights of passengers in bus and coach transport SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 181/2011 concerning the rights of passengers in bus and coach transport WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It aims to ensure a high level of protection for passengers in the event of accidents arising out of the use of the bus or coach. KEY POINTS Scope The regulation applies to all passengers travelling by bus or coach in the EU. It does not apply to passengers travelling by train, air or sea. It does not apply to passengers travelling by train, air or sea. Rights of passengers in bus and coach transport The regulation applies to all passengers travelling by bus or coach in the EU. It does not apply to passengers travelling by train, air or sea. Scope The regulation applies to all passengers travelling by bus or coach in the EU. It does not apply to passengers travelling by train, air or sea. It does not apply to passengers travelling by train, air or sea. ACT Regulation (EU) No 181/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 February 2011 concerning the rights of passengers in bus and coach transport and amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 (OJ L 55, 28.2.2011, pp. 1-8) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) No 181/2011 have been incorporated into the basic text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Statistics on aquaculture Statistics on aquaculture SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 762/2008 on the submission by EU countries of statistics on aquaculture Regulation (EC) No 788/96 on the submission by EU countries of statistics on aquaculture Regulation (EC) No 788/96 on the submission by EU countries of statistics on aquaculture Regulation (EC) No 788/96 on the submission by EU countries of statistics on aquaculture Regulation (EC) No 762/2008 on the submission by EU countries of statistics on aquaculture WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATIONS? Regulation (EC) No 762/2008 and Regulation (EC) No 788/96 require EU countries to submit annual statistics on the volume and value of aquaculture production. Scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries Scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EU) No 1236/2010 laying down a scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It lays down a scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries. KEY POINTS The regulation applies to vessels flying the flag of a contracting party and operating in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries. It also applies to vessels flying the flag of a non-contracting party and operating in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries. The regulation sets out inspection and surveillance procedures and infringement procedures for vessels flying the flag of a contracting party and operating in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries. Inspection and surveillance procedures The regulation sets out inspection and surveillance procedures and infringement procedures for vessels flying the flag of a contracting party and operating in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries. The regulation also sets out inspection and surveillance procedures and infringement procedures for vessels flying the flag of a non-contracting party and operating in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries. Inspection and surveillance procedures The regulation sets out inspection and surveillance procedures and infringement procedures for vessels flying the flag of a contracting party and operating in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries. The regulation also sets out inspection and surveillance procedures and infringement procedures for vessels flying the flag of a non-contracting party and operating in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries. The regulation also sets out inspection and surveillance procedures and infringement procedures for vessels flying the flag of a non-contracting party and operating in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries. FROM WHEN DOES THE REGULATION APPLY? It has applied since 1 January 2011. BACKGROUND For more information, see: North-East Atlantic fisheries (European Commission). MAIN DOCUMENT Regulation (EU) No 1236/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 15 December 2010 laying down a scheme of control and enforcement applicable in the area covered by the Convention on future multilateral cooperation in the North-East Atlantic fisheries and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2791/1999 (OJ L 348, 31.12.2010, pp. 17-19) Successive amendments to Regulation (EU) No 1236/2010 have been incorporated into the original text. This consolidated version is of documentary value only. Summary 176:
EU eco-label scheme EU eco-label scheme SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 66/2010 on the EU Ecolabel WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION? It sets out the rules for the EU eco-label award scheme, which aims to promote products with a reduced environmental impact during their entire life cycle and to provide consumers with accurate, non-deceptive, science-based information on the environmental impact of products. KEY POINTS The EU Ecolabel is a voluntary eco-label award scheme, which aims to promote products with a reduced environmental impact during their entire life cycle and to provide consumers with accurate, non-deceptive, science-based information on the environmental impact of products. The EU Ecolabel is based on a set of criteria, which are based on scientific evidence, taking into consideration the latest technological developments. The criteria are simple to understand and to use, and are limited to the most significant environmental impacts of products during their whole life cycle. These criteria are market oriented and are based on scientific evidence, taking into consideration the latest technological developments. The EU Ecolabel is a voluntary eco-label award scheme, which aims to promote products with a reduced environmental impact during their entire life cycle and to provide consumers with accurate, non-deceptive, science-based information on the environmental impact of products. Summary 178:
Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters SUMMARY OF: Regulation (EC) No 44/2001 on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters WHAT IS THE AIM OF THE REGULATION AND THE CONVENTION? Regulation (EC) No 44/2001 sets out the rules for the application of the 1968 Brussels Convention on jurisdiction and the enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters, as amended by the Accession Conventions under the successive enlargements of the European Union (EU), and the Lugano Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters, which extends the application of the rules of the 1968 Brussels Convention to certain States members of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA). The Geneva Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters sets out the rules for the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters, as amended by the Accession Conventions under the successive enlargements of the European Union (EU), and the Lugano Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters, which extends the application of the rules of the Lugano Convention to certain States members of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA). KEY POINTS The regulation sets out the rules for the application of the 1968 Brussels Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters, as amended by the Accession Conventions under the successive enlargements of the European Union (EU), and the Lugano Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters, which extends the application of the rules of the 1968 Brussels Convention to certain States members of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA). The Geneva Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters sets out the rules for the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters, as amended by the Accession Conventions under the successive enlargements of the European Union (EU), and the Lugano Convention on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters, which extends the application of the rules of the 1968 Brussels Convention to certain States members of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA).
